loans.name: Narzullo

texts.en:
R. Narzullo is 48 years old. He is married and has one child. His main work consists of breeding cattle. This very remunerative activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, Narzullo would like to buy a greater number of cattle and to build a farmhouse to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of $800 USD for the realization of this project. When his dream is carried out, Narzullo will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his growing family. With your help, this will be possible.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is a 35-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of four and 12 years.  All of her children go to school. 

She rents a three room house where she is staying with five people. Prossy takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. 

She incurs transportation costs to and from shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest markets in the city of Kampala.  She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. 

Prossy works seven days a week. She has a ladies salon in Kibuye on Kampala-Entebbe Highway. She receives an average of seven customers a day and works on all categories of people.  She also sells creams at retail price to any customer. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of hair conditioners and hair extensions. She has been in this business for over seven years and with MCDT for eight years and is servicing her twentieth loan. 

In addition to a banana business, she also sells beer at her home. 

Prossy joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with.  She wants to use this loan to buy more hair extensions and conditioners.

loans.use: To buy more hair conditioners and extensions (weaves,braids)

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is excited to have a Kiva loan. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling drinks, which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children. She is 38 years old and married with five children. She sells drinks. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase drinks in bulk

loans.name: A. Pauline

texts.fr: G. A. Pauline est née en 1970 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Pauline vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis 15 ans. Mariée à VEZOUNDAN Justin, un chauffeur, Pauline est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Pauline a deux autres enfants à charge. Pauline vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Pauline n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école. Depuis près de 20 ans, Pauline vend des tissus (bazins) par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Pauline s’approvisionne. Pauline est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue d’augmenter le stock de ses produits afin de faire face à la demande de la clientèle en période de préparation des fêtes de fin d’année, Pauline sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. A. Pauline was born in 1970 in Allada, in the county of Atlantique in Benin. For the past 15 years, Pauline has lived in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Vezoundan Justin, a driver; Pauline is the mother of four children, all of whom are attending school. Pauline also cares for two additional children. Pauline lives with her husband and their children. She did not have the opportunity to go to school. For the past 20 years, Pauline has sold fabric ("bazins"- a traditional West African fabric) through her distribution system. She supplies herself in Dantokpa, which is Benin's international market. Pauline is an old client of ALIDé and has fully repaid her previous loans. In order to increase her business' stock and to satisfy her clientele's requests in preparation for the end of year holidays, Pauline is requesting a third loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cloth in bulk.

loans.name: Kurbanboy

texts.en:
D. Kurbanboy is 44 years old. He is married with five children. Kurbanboy is an optimistic and hardworking father. He works his land with love and dedication every day, so that it produces excellent vegetables. Kurbanboy has been is in the agro business for more than nine years. In fact, he draws strength and vitality to make his products the best in the city. Though growing vegetables is a very difficult and time taking job, he hopes to gather a rich harvest. He is planning to fix his house and save enough money to pay for his children’s school fees. With this purpose, he is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni. With the desire to realize his plan, Kurbanboy appeals to your generous hearts for a swift contribution.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zebiniso

texts.en:
H. Zebiniso is 53 years old and married with two children of school age. As any mother, she wants her children to have everything they need and is dreaming that all of them will have a higher education.

Her husband is a farmer. Zebiniso is a farmer, too. She has been working the land for twenty years and in that time has gained much experience and a love for the land. She began cultivating her land through her own efforts and has gradually gotten ahead in life. Zebiniso grows corn and onions. This business is one of her greatest accomplishments.

She wishes to continue to generate income for her children's development, and for this reason she is requesting a loan of 3,500 TJS. Zebiniso is planning to purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. She thanks everyone who trusts her and supports her today. loans.use: to purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is 55 years old and married with two children. She sells household items to be able to meet her family's needs. She hopes to expand her business and increase her stock. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more household items to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more household items  to sell

loans.name: Hortense

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Hortense est mariée à SEBLONOUDO Paul et est mère de quatre enfants. Hortense a quatre autres enfants à charge, en plus de ces enfants. Certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Hortense réside depuis près de 15 ans à Cadjèhoun, un quartier de Cotonou. C’est avec ses enfants et son mari que Hortense vit. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Hortense est allée à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Hortense vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs, accompagnée de sauce) à la devanture de sa maison. Hortense fait ses achats à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Dans l’optique d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de produire davantage de repas, afin d’augmenter sa clientèle, Hortense sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, A. Hortense is married to Seblonoudo Paul and is the mother of four children. In addition to her own children, Hortense cares for four additional children. Some of the children are currently attending school. For the past 15 years, Hortense has lived in Cadjèhoun, a neighborhood of Cotonou. Hortense lives with her children and her husband. Together, the couple takes care of their family's expenses. Hortense was educated through secondary school. In order to take care of her needs, Hortense sells food (rice, corn paste, the accompanying sauces) from the store-window in her home. Hortense supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is an old client of ALIDé and has previously received two loans, both of which have been fully repaid. In order to increase her business' funds and produce more meals, so that she can grow her clientele, Hortense is requesting a third loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice and corn, 1 container of vegetable oil

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a 47-year-old single mother of two children who are 19 and 21 years of age.  Both of her children go to school. She rents a two room house where she is staying with three people. 

Margret takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  

She incurs transportation costs to and from buying electronics in Kiyembe and some shops near Nakasero market, one of the busiest markets in the city of Kampala. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. 

Margret works six days a week.  She receives an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on both a retail and wholesale basis. She has a shop selling electronics on Lubaga Road, Kitawuluzi Zone, and sells all types of of electronics, both new and used ones.  In addition to her electronics business, she has a stall selling fruits. 

Her major business challenges are the ever-increasing prices of electronics, and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her because she works in a muddy place.  

Margret has been in this business for three years and with MCDT for six years.  She is servicing her twelfth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more electronics like flat irons, electric wires, extension cables, kettles, and plugs, She is hoping to see her business grow bigger so she can start selling on a wholesale only basis.

loans.use: To buy more electronics like kettles, plugs, extensions, cables and flat irons

loans.name: Sairi

texts.en:
I. Sairi is 45 years old and married, and she is the loving mother of four children. Sairi’s husband is currently unemployed, so her business is the main source of income for her family.

Sairi has a grocery store where she sells sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks, detergents and other products. She has been in this business for more than twenty years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Sairi is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her store to buy groceries again. Sairi wants to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of $800 to increase the inventory she has for sale.

One of her dreams is that her children progress by means of their studies. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Sairi realize all of her aspirations. loans.use: to increase the inventory she has for sale

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.fr: K. Alphonsine est née en 1979 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Alphonsine réside depuis sa naissance au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou.  C’est une divorcée et mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Alphonsine vit avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Alphonsine a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis environs cinq ans, pour satisfaire ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Alphonsine vend des divers (conserves, tasses et assiettes en séries, lait, sardine) de même que des liqueurs et des boissons (sucreries et bières) dans sa boutique à Cadjèhoun. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Alphonsine s’approvisionne. Alphonsine a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’étendre son activité et de satisfaire plus les demandes de sa clientèle en période de fêtes de fin d'année, Alphonsine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Alphonsine was born in 1979 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Since her birth, Alphonsine has lived in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou. She is divorced and the mother of two children, both of whom are attending school. Alphonsine lives with her children and takes care of her family's expenses alone. Alphonsine stopped attending school after secondary school. For about the last 5 year, in order to satisfy her needs and those of her children, Alphonsine has sold a variety of goods (jams, cups and plates, milk, sardines), liquors and drinks (sodas and beers) in her store in Cadjèhoun. Alphonsine supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Alphonsine has already had two loans with ALIDé, both of which were fully repaid. In order to expand her business and better satisfy the needs of her clientele for the end of year holidays, Alphonsine is requesting a third loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase drinks (sodas, beers, liquors)

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba is a very diligent woman of 37 years. She is married with four children. Her husband is a farmer. Thanks to her dear parents' seeding skills, she is very familiar with agriculture work. Her loving father gave her fields to farm twelve years ago and she's been working them ever since. This activity has helped to pay the economic expenses of her family.

Nasiba's wishes to improve the quality of her products drove her to request a loan of 4500 TJS to acquire seeds and mineral fertilizers in order to obtain excellent products for this harvesting season. Please help make her request possible so that this hardworking mother can continue to sustain her work with a lot of satisfaction. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. loans.use: to purchaseing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is focused and hard working. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. She is 35 years old and married with four children.

She sells provisions very close to her house, and has been in this business for the past eight years. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN which she intends to use to buy provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: K. G. Marie est née en 1952 à Bohicon, dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Marie réside depuis environs 25 ans à Cadjèhoun, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à TOBADE SATCHA Philippe, un retraité du Ministère des Finances au Bénin, Marie est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Marie a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Marie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son conjoint. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Marie n’a fait que le cours primaire, à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Marie vend des vêtements (friperies) et également des divers (arachide grillé, sucre en poudre, farine de manioc, etc.) à la devanture de sa maison. C’est à Missèbo, un marché de friperies au Bénin, que Marie s’approvisionne. Marie a obtenu déjà deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Marie souhaite augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir son activité, afin d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire. C’est pourquoi Marie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. G. Marie Was born in 1952 in Bohicon, in the county of Zou in Benin. For the past 25 years, Marie has lived in Cadjèhoun, a nieghborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Marie is married to Tobade Satcha Philippe, who is retired from his work with the Ministry of Finance in Benin. Marie is the mother of three children, all of whom are attending school. Marie has one other child in her care, in addition to her own children. Marie lives with her children and her spouse. The couple takes care of the family's expenses together. Marie only attending primary school. In order to provide for her family's need, Marie sells clothes (second-hand) and also sells a variety of goods (grilled peanuts, powdered sugar, manioc flour, etc.) from the store-front in her home. Marie gets her supplies in Missèbo, a second-hand clothing market in Benin. Marie has already obtained two loans from ALIDé, both of which were properly repaid. Marie wants to increase the funds for her business and expand her business, in order to increase her sales. This is why Marie is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothing for resale

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana S. is 34 years old and she lives in Kapan with her school-aged son. Liana is an economist and before that she worked as a shop assistant for some years.

Three months ago Liana organized a mixed-product trade in a rented place and she has approximately 85,000 AMD in income from her business. Liana’s shop, where she sells food, household goods and clothes, is open on weekdays.

Liana seeks a 500,000 AMD loan to buy a New Year’s assortment for her shop: candy, juice, citruses and sausages.

loans.use: To buy a New Year’s assortment for her shop

loans.name: Tuichiboy

texts.en: S. Tuichiboy is a father who has devoted himself to independent agriculture tasks for the past six years, cultivating corn, potatoes and onions. His daily efforts and the care of his fields assure him a good harvest as well as profits, so that his 4 children can continue their education. Tuichiboy has dreamed of extending his lands and wants to obtain a loan to invest in his current land by purchasing seeds and fertilizer to earn greater profits and reach the goal he has set for himself. He thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan with no violations. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Justine

texts.fr: S. Justine est née le 07 Mai 1971 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Justine est mariée à GBAGUIDI Parfait, un animateur rural. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Justine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. C’est depuis 12 ans que Justine vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. Justine n’a fait que le cours primaire à l’école, mais a appris le métier de coiffure. Depuis 10 ans de cela, Justine vend des produits cosmétiques et de beauté dans son atelier de coiffure. Justine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle en période de préparation des fêtes de fin d’année, Justine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Justine was born May 7th, 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Justine is married to Gbaguidi Parfait, who is a rural educator. The couple has four children, all of whom attend school and live in their care. Together with her husband, Justine takes care of the family's expenses. For the past 12 years, Justine has lived in the Cadjèhoun neighborhood of Cotonou. Justine only attended primary school, but she learned the trade of hairstyling. For the past 10 years, Justine has sold cosmetics and beauty products in her hair salon. Justine supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. As an old client of ALIDé, Justine has fully repaid her previous loans. In order to increase her product stock and better satisfy the needs of her large clientele during the period of preparing for the end of year holidays, Justine is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair weaves and beauty products

loans.name: Varduhi

texts.en:
Varduhi S. lives in Yerevan with her husband and two school-aged daughters. Varduhi graduated from the teachers training college and worked at the Nalbandyan School for about 10 years.

5 years ago she rented a shop where she creates flower arrangements and wedding baskets and offers accessories for sale. Varduhi’s husband works in the soft drinks and alcohol trade at the trade fair. Varduhi is requesting a $3,000 loan to expand her business, so she can rent evening dresses in her shop.

loans.use: Offer evening dresses for rent in her shop

loans.name: Sessimè

texts.fr: A. Sessimè est née en 1975 à Adja au Mono au Bénin. Mariée à KOUDE Antoine un agent de sécurité, Sessimè est mère de quatre enfants. Trois autres enfants sont à sa charge. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Sessimè vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis une dizaine d’année. Sessimè n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a 8 ans de cela que Sessimè vend des produits vivriers (riz, haricot, maïs, etc.) dans son quartier à Cadjèhoun. Sessimè fait ses emplettes à Dantopa, marché international du Bénin. Sessimè a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’agrandir son activité et de mieux satisfaire la forte demande des clients en période de préparation des fêtes, Sessimè sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.Sessimè envisage plus tard acheter sa propre parcelle, grâce aux économies issues de la vente de ses articles.
texts.en:
A. Sessimè was born in 1975 in Adja, in Mono, Benin. Married to KOUDE Antoine, a security guard, she is the mother of four children. Three other children are in her care. Some of the children are in school. For twelve years, she has been living together with her children and husband in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Sessimè has not gone to school. For eight years, she has been selling staple foods (rice, beans, corn, etc.) in her district in Cadjèhoun. She makes her purchases at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already obtained two ALIDé loans, which have been repaid. With the aim of expanding her business and satisfying further the strong customer demand during preparations for the holidays, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Sessimè envisions buying her own parcel of land later on, with the help of the savings from selling her merchandise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sacks of rice and beans

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a young Palestinian man, 29 years old. He is married with three young children.

Ali is a police officer in the Palestinian National Authority and his monthly salary hardly covers his family’s daily expenses Unfortunately, one of his children, aged five years, is suffering from a disease of the blood which requires special health treatment in addition to lots of medicine.

Ali requested 500 USD from FATEN to buy medicine and pay some of the medical fees for his child, Ali knows that this kind of problem will be eternal with his child and he will always depend on medicine to survive. He decided to take small amount of money to meet his current need and at the same time the monthly payment is affordable. 

Ali appears in the photo at FATEN office.

loans.use: To buy his child's medicine

location.town: Idna Village, Hebron City, West Bank

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: H. Célestine est née en 1969 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Célestine est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C’est une divorcée, vivant seule avec ses enfants au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestine réside dans ce quartier depuis 10 ans. C’est Célestine qui assure seule les charges de la famille. Célestine n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a 8 ans déjà que Célestine mène comme activité, la vente de pâtés (faits à base de farine de blé). Célestine vend également de l’huile végétale ainsi que des produits vivriers (maïs, haricot) à son domicile et par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Célestine fait ses achats. Célestine a obtenu deux fois déjà de crédits à ALIDé et les a bien remboursés. Célestine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé afin d’agrandir davantage son activité et d’attirer plus la clientèle.
texts.en:
H. Célestine was born in 1969 in Allada, in Atlantique county, Benin. She is the mother of four children who are all in school. She is divorced and living alone with her children in the Cadjèhoun district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been residing in this district for ten years. She alone ensures that family needs are met. Célestine did not go to school. For eight years already, she has been running a business selling pâtés (made with wheat flour). She also sells vegetable oil, as well as staple foods (corn, beans) out of her home and by the distribution system. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she makes her purchases. She twice had an ALIDé loan and has repaid them. She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé to expand her business further and to attract more customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wheat flour, corn, and beans

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing sells food spices like salt, tomato paste, ginger and curry at retail prices to her customers. This is the festive season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during and after the season. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family.

She is 42 years old and married with five children. All her children are schooling. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more food spices to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food spices to sell

loans.name: Judite Jacinto

texts.pt:
Judite António M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 37 anos de vida, casada e mãe de 5 filhos de 22, 20, 17, 15 e 11 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 6ª classe porque quando foi ao lar o marido não lhe deixou continuar. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, não sustenta mais ninguém para alem da sua família.

Nunca mudou do Distrito, apenas mudou de bairro quando se juntou ao seu marido. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 15 anos. Aprendeu esta actividade com suas irmãs há mais de 25 anos, vende mais ovos que está a 680.00mt caixa e rende cerca de 7.000.00mt por mês. Poupa algum na sua conta bancária, no Banco Comercial Barclays.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua irmã que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 5º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (ovos, vinhos, refrescos cervejas e outros) para satisfazer o seu mercado. Os créditos anteriores foram de 10.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, 15.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para melhorar ainda mais a qualidade de serviços que oferece a sua clientela e apostar na educação de seus filhos.
texts.en:
Judite António M. was born in the district of Boane, Maputo province. She is 37 years old, married, and mother of five children, who are 22, 20, 17, 15 and 11 years old. All of them go to school. She did only up to the 6th grade because when she became a housewife her husband did not allow her to continue. She lives in her own house with her family, and does not support anyone beyond her family members.

She has never left the Boane district. She moved only to another neighborhood when she got together with her husband. She has her own business for more than 15 years. She has learned this activity from her sisters, more than 25 years ago. The product that she sells the most is eggs, which cost MZN 680 a box, and which provides her an income of MZN 7,000 a month. She saves some money on her savings account, at the commercial bank Barclays.

She has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through her sister, who is also one of the institution's clients. This is her 5th loan, of MZN 20,000, with which she intends to buy products (eggs, wine, beverages, beer and others) in order to please her market. Her previous loans were of MZN 10,000; MZN 10,000; MZN 15,000; and MZN 15,000, all of them for the same activity.

In the future, she intends to request more loans in order to improve even more the quality of the services she offers to her customers, and to invest on her children's education.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and selling of beverages

loans.name: Tomas Felix

texts.pt:
Tomas Félix M. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, junto a fronteira com a Suazilândia, na Província de Maputo, tem 28 anos de idade, viúvo e pai de 2 filhos de 5 e 2 anos. Fez somente 8ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos seus progenitores. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos e mais 2 irmãos sobre seu sustento.

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane com os pais por causa da guerra, devido a varias dificuldades encaradas, decidiu iniciar o seu próprio negocio. Faz cerca de 10 horas de trabalho por dia e conta com um empregado que lhe auxilia neste trabalho. O seu rendimento mensal é de cerca de 10.000.00mt que aplica no sustento da família e poupa algum na sua conta bancária através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa). 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus amigos que fazem a mesma actividade. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, varões de ferro, barrotes e outros) para poder cobrir uma parte da sua casa. O empréstimo anterior foi de 10.000.00mt para a mesma actividade. 

Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e oferecer melhores condições de habitação a sua família.
texts.en:
Tomas Félix M. was born in the district of Namaacha, close to the Suazilândia border, in the province of Maputo. He is 28 years old, widow, and father of two children of 5 and 2 years old. He did only up to the 8th grade at school. He did not continue because his parents had no condition to afford it. He lives in his own house with his two children plus two brothers, all of whom he supports.

He left Namaacha to Boane with his parents because of the war. Due to several difficulties he faced, he decided to begin his own business. He works about 10 hours a day, and has an employee help him. His monthly income is of approximately MZN 10,000, which he applies on supporting his family, as well as on saving on his bank account through Xitique (rotational traditional savings system).

He has never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through his friends, who do the same activity as him. This is his second loan, of MZN 15,000, with which he intends to buy construction materials (zinc sheets, iron rods, beams and others) in order to cover part of his house. His previous loan was of MZN 10,000, for the same activity.

In the future, he intends to request more loans to conclude his house construction and provide better housing conditions to his family.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials (construction sheets, beams and others)

loans.name: Rabeca

texts.pt:
Rabeca H. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 43 anos de idade, separada e mãe de 5 filhos de 24, 22, 19, 16, e 7 anos de idade, 4 destes vão a escola. Fez somente 6ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos em Boane e ainda sustenta um sobrinho e 1 neto.

Nunca mudou de cidade, depois de casamento continuou a viver no mesmo Distrito. Tem um negócio Próprio, vende das 7h as 19h a mais de 25 anos, trabalha sozinha e rende cerca de 4.000.00mt por mês. Consegue poupar algum valor através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos e seus vizinhos. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, blocos, cimento e areia) para ampliar a sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 5.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt todos para comércio.

No futuro espera solicitar mais empréstimos para dar continuidade com a sua obra e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família assim como reforçar o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Rabeca H. was born in the district of Boane in the province of Maputo. She is 43, separated, and has 5 children who are 24, 22, 19, 16, and 7. Four of her children go to school. She only studied through 6th grade and didn't continue because of a lack of money. She lives in her own home with her children in Boane and she also supports a nephew and a grandson. She never moved out of her city. After she got married, she continued to live in the same district. She has her own business and has sold from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. for more than 25 years. She works alone and earns about 4,000 meticais per month. She manages to save some through a traditional rotating savings system known as Xitique. She has never had a loan with another bank. She became familiar with Hluvuku through friends and neighbors. This is her 4th loan and it is for 15,000 meticais. She will use it to purchase construction materials (metals sheets, bricks, cement, and sand) to expand her home. Her previous loans were for 5,000, 10,000, and 10,000 meticais, all of which were used for her business. In the future she hopes to request more loans to continue working on her home so she can offer better living conditions to her family and strengthen her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (bricks and cement)

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa loves cooking and that is why she commercialized her cooking skills. She sells Nigerian cooked foods like rice, eba (a staple food made from cassava flour) and moi-moi (steamed bean cake). Customer demand for her cooked food is high and she hopes to be able to meet it. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. 

She is 41 years old and married with five children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Firmino Afonso

texts.pt:
Fermino C. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Capital de Moçambique, tem 57 anos de idade, casado e pai de 5 filhos de 28, 26, 23, 19, e 15 anos de idade, destes os 3 mais de velhos vão a escola. Fez 1º ano no Instituto Industrial, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família no bairro Luís Cabral e sustenta 2 pessoas, neto e sobrinho que vivem com ele.

Nunca mudou de residência é comerciante dono do seu negócio e trabalha na SEMOC (sementes de Moçambique) como chefe dos recursos humanos a mais de 9 anos. Na empresa onde trabalha tem um salário mensal de 9.750.00mt e no negócio ganha ate 3.000.00mt por semana e poupa algum na sua conta bancária. Vende mais carne, farinha, bebidas secas e outros. 

Já teve empréstimos na cooperativa de créditos TCHUMA e mais tarde conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus colegas tendo decidido solicitar o seu 1º empréstimo. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos para vender (farinha, bebidas, carnes e outros) no seu estabelecimento. O empréstimo anterior foi de 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para poder expandir o seu negócio e ainda com perspectiva criar frangos de corte
texts.en:
Fermino C. was born in the city of Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. He is 57; married; and the father of 5 children who are 28, 26, 23, 19, and 15. His 3 oldest children go to school. He studied for one year at the Industrial Institute and didn't continue due to the lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family in the Luís Cabral neighborhood and also supports his grandson and nephew who live with him. He has never moved to another home. He is a merchant and owner of his own business and has also worked at SEMOC (which stands for Seeds of Mozambique) as the head of human resources for 9 years. At the company where he works, he earns a monthly salary of 9,750 meticais and at his business, he earns 3,000 meticais per week. He saves some of it in his bank account. He sells meat, flour, beverages, and other items. He has had loans with another credit organization known as TCHUMA and later became familiar with Hluvuku through his colleagues, so he decided to request his first loan. This is his 2nd loan with Hluvuku. His previous loan was for 15,000 meticais and was used for the same purpose. In the future he hopes to request more loans to be able to expand his business, which he plans to do by raising chickens to butcher.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell drinks, meat, and soft drinks

loans.name: Constance

texts.en: Constance sells medicines at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a maternity home in the future. She is 57 years old and married with five children. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Wala'a

texts.en:
Ala'a is a young Palestinian women who lives in at Biet Hanoun in the Northen Gaza Strip, Ala'a is newly married and pregnant with her first child. 

Ala'a and her husband own a computer repair shop where her husband fixes computers. They also sell new and used computers and rend and sell DVDs and CDs. Ala'a helps her husband by running the shop while he is out or while he is fixing the computers. She sells the CDs and DVDs. They started the business together two years ago. 

Ala'a and her husband have requested $2000 USD from FATEN to buy new computers and CDs to sell. 

In the photograph, Ala'a and her husband appear in the shop where they fix computers.

loans.use: Buy computers and CDs

loans.name: Samuel Joaquim

texts.pt:
Samuel Joaquim S. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de mesmo nome, capital de Moçambique, tem 51 anos de idade, pai de 9 filhos de idades entre 18 a 28 anos de idade 2 destes vão a escola. Fez 4ª classe do antigo sistema de Educação, não continuou por falta de condições financeiras pelos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família no Distrito de Boane, e não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Saiu da cidade da Matola para Boane afim de fixar um estabelecimento farmacêutico e tendo mais tarde decido mudar a sua residência para este local. É negociante e dono do seu negócio há mais de 20 anos e conta com 4 trabalhadores. Consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt a 5.000.00mt que aplica no sustento da família, pagamento dos trabalhadores e ainda poupa algum no banco comercial (BIM e BCI).

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga e decidiu solicitar o seu 1º empréstimo. O presente credita é o 3º no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (100 sacos de cimento) para produzir blocos da sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 8.500.00mt os dois, ambos para a mesma actividade.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e aumentar a oferta de serviços do seu negócio.
texts.en:
Samuel Joaquim S. was born in the city of Maputo in the province of the same name, which is the capital of Mozambique. He is 51 and is the father of 9 children whose ages range from 18 to 28. Two of them go to school. He studied through the 4th grade of the old school system and didn't continue because of his parents' lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family in the district of Boane. He doesn't support anyone besides his immediate family. He left Matola for Boane to start a pharmacy business and later decided to move his home to this location. He has owned his own business for 20 years and has 4 employees. He makes a monthly income of 4,000 to 5,000 meticais and uses it to support his family, pay his workers, and save some in a commercial bank (BIM or BCI). He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through a friend and decided to request his first loan. This is his third credit and it is for 15,000 meticais. He will use it to purchase construcion materials (100 bags of cement) to produce bricks for his home. His previous loans were both for 8,500 meticais and both were used for the same activity. In the future he hopes to request more loans to finish his home and to expand the services he offers at his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials (cement, bricks, etc.)

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma S. is 62 years old, married to Felimon L. S., and currently living at Prinza, Teresa Rizal. She is engaged in a hog-fattening business (raising of pigs) with the support of her loving husband. 

She has six children, the eldest being 41 years old and the youngest 24. Five of her children have graduated as degree holders through loans from the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI). 

Norma S. will use the loan for raising more pigs, and for the expansion of her future hog-farming business, in order to support her family in a stable life. She hopes to see herself enjoying the profits of her business and to have a good life. 

She is also enjoying the benefit of having loans from ASHI because she can gradually achieve her goals in life. During almost three years with ASHI Norma S. has shown herself to be industrious, and to have determination and discipline. She gives all of her time for her family and business for the fulfillment of family dreams. They would love to have their own car someday.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to grow her business

loans.name: Layidou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Layidou est  composé de quatre femmes mariées dont deux dans des familles monogames. Elles ont  en moyenne  39 ans, 3 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Bagadadji Sud communément appelé ATT-Bougou de la ville de  Ségou  (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens d’amitié car elles ont fait leur enfance ensemble à Bougoufié et de voisinage avec l’avènement des logements sociaux (ATT Bougou). 
Après six prêts de groupe tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur 7ème prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Ce prêt  servira à acheter, 52 sacs de charbon de bois,  15 pièces de pagnes wax, des produits pour la  restauration (tels que du couscous arabe,  30 sachets d’1kg, 60 sachets de spaghetti, 25 sachets de macaroni Sobipal, 25kg de haricot, 1 bidon de 20l d’huile alimentaire sans cholestérol) et des ingrédients (75 bols  de « gueni », 15flacons d’eau de Cologne, 15flacons de parfum) pour l’encens varient selon les périodes.  
Elles s’approvisionnent en pâtes alimentaires dans une Alimentation à Hamdallaye, le haricot est fourni à domicile par les forains des villages voisins, en pagnes wax au grand marché de Ségou  chez les  « Djogoramé », en gueni, eau de Cologne, parfums au marché château, en charbon de bois auprès des exploitants de Sakoïba. Les aliments sont vendus  les jours de foire de Ségou au marché de Médine et les jours ordinaires à domicile surtout au comptant, les pagnes wax sont vendus au marché de Ségou- Coura et à domicile, l’encens est vendu sur commande à Bamako et dans les structures telles :Alpha log,  le Trésor, l’APSRU (Association pour la Promotion du Secteur Rural et Urbain), l’INPS (Institut National de Prévoyance Sociale), le charbon est vendu à domicile en détail et en demi gros à crédit. La vente de leurs marchandises se fait   au comptant et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel  de 37.000FCFA à 42.100FCFA   qui servira à rembourser les prêts, à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux, à l’achat de fournitures scolaires et à participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage et funérailles).
texts.en:
The Layidou group is made up of four married women, two of whom are in monogamous families. They average 39-years-old, with 3 children, and live in the Bagadadji Sud quarter - usually called ATT-Bougou - in the village of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali). They are friends as they grew up together in Bougoufié and were neighbors in public housing (ATT Bougou). After six repaid group loans, they are together for their seventh loan with Soro Yiriwaso. This loan will serve to buy 52 bags of wooden charcoal, 15 pieces of wax pagne cloth, catering products (some Arabic couscous, 30 1-kilogram bags, 60 bags of spaghetti, 25 bags of Sobipal macaroni, 25 kg of beans, 1 can of 20L cholesterol-free cooking oil) and ingredients for various types of incense (75 bowls of gueni - good smelling roots that grow in humid areas and are used in making incense - 15 bottles of perfume water, 15 perfume bottles). They stock up on pasta in a shop in Hamdallaye; the beans are produced at home by neighboring village farmers; the wax pagne cloth is from the Djogorames at the grand market of Ségou; the gueni, perfume water and perfume come from the castle market; and the wood charcoal is from farmers in Sakoiba. The food is sold at the Ségou-Coura market fair and from home; the incense is made-to-order in Bamako for the following organizations: Alpha log, le Trésor, l'APSRU (Association for the Promotion of the Rural and Urban Sector), l'INPS (National Institute of Social Forethought); the charcoal is sold at home at retail and wholesale prices. Their merchandise sales are done in both cash and credit to male and female customers. They plan on making a monthly profit of 37,000 to 42,100 FCFA which will serve to repay the loan, support their small family needs, purchase school supplies, and participate in social events (baptisms, marriages, and funerals).

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of varied items

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Success in life totally depends on how one handles and manages the opportunities that come your way. When it comes to family life, success depends on how each partner cooperates and supports the other in all endeavors.

Rosalie P. has always been open to new opportunities that come her way, especially in business. She is always on the lookout for new possibilities where she could use her skills and business acumen. Because she is not afraid to work hard to achieve her goals, she has already accomplished a lot in her 46 years.

Rosalie is married to Pedrito, who is a councilor in their village. Even though he is active in local politics, Pedrito is also an active partner in their hollow blocks factory.

They have four children. The two older ones have already earned their college degrees, and the younger kids are still in school. Rosalie's immediate aspiration is for her two remaining children to finish their studies and for their hollow blocks factory to continue to flourish, enabling them to provide employment to more people in their community in Brgy. Cabatangan, Talisay City, Negros Occidental.

Rosalie's financial situation today is so much improved from her life years ago. Her first business was a "sari-sari" or general store where she sold just a few items. She was very frugal in budgeting her income, making sure that she set aside some of the income to increase her working capital, but she realized that she could not expand her business if she did not have access to outside capital. This is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in June of 2002. With the additional capital, she was able to increase her income capacity by adding more items to her goods for sale. Later, she also started selling Ready-to-Wear clothes, and then added a Water Refilling Station to her roster of services. With the additional businesses, she hired people to help her in the business.

When she was given the opportunity to start a Hollow Blocks Factory, she did not hesitate, because she knew that this would not only help her family, but also provide work opportunities for people in their village. All her business activities now earn a minimum of $293 a month. She saves most of her income for the education of her children and their household expenses. In her previous loan she borrowed 35,000 PHP which she used as working capital for her business ventures. Now that she is into her next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 38,000 PHP so that she can buy another hollow-blocks machine and increase her production capacity.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for making hollow blocks

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 45 years old and married with seven children. Her children are excelling in school. She sells tubers of yam at wholesale and retail prices to her customers in Benin city. She is a focused, hard worker. She has been in this business for a long time. The demand for her tubers of yam is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits this season. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yam to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Siama

texts.en:
Siama T. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more chairs and tables in order to seat more customers. Siama is 40 years old and married. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more chairs and tables in order to seat more customers.

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en: Nasser is a 28-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children. He has been working as a farmer since 2004 with a previous twelve year experience in the field. Nasser is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy tools for his farm in order to complete his work and satisfy the needs of his customers.

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob Ikerhie is 24 years old and married with one child. His child has not started school because he is not up to school age.

Jacob has a stall where he sells groceries and rechargeable phone cards at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to be a major distributor of rechargeable phone cards in the future.

He is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and rechargeable phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M. Valdes is 63 years old and is married to Rodolfo V. who is a carpenter with an average of income of 250 PHP per day. The couple has 9 children; the eldest son is 39 years old and the youngest is Ricky, 21 years old. Seven of her children have finished studies in college and 2 of them are currently at college.

Lydia and Rodolfo have been engaged in backyard hog raising (raising of pigs) for almost 9 years and have been a member of Ashi for almost 5 years. Their business has been the biggest support in meeting their day-to-day needs, especially in the schooling of their children.

Through her perseverance and being a good mother Lydia sent all her children to college. She could do so through the help of her business because her husband’s income as a carpenter could not pay for the education of her children. That is why Lydia V. started in this business which also support the dreams of her 9 children.

They dream that someday their business will grow and that in the future they will have a stable hog farming business and a good life. Lydia is requesting 25,000 PHP for additional capital for her hog raising business to continue her fight and rise up from poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for the growth of her business.

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 20 year-old single man living with his parents and two brothers.

In 2006, Youssef opened his own barber shop.

Today, Youssef is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy some tools for his work. This loan will help him keep up his business activities by increasing his sales as well as his income.

loans.use: To buy some tools.

loans.name: Fatema

texts.en:
Fatema is a young Palestinian woman who is married with two children.

Fatema’s husband used to work in Israel but after the closure they decided to open their own business. Two years ago they started this sewing workshop and currently they have five sewing machines. They both work in the workshop. They obtain cut cloth which they sew, in addition to making special designs upon request.

Fatema requested 2,000 USD from FATEN to buy some cloth and to buy a new sewing machine. They hope that after the loan they will hire a new employee to help them in the workshop.

Fatemah and her husband appear in the photo at their workshop.

loans.use: To purchase some cloth and to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin E. K. is 33 years old and married with 2 children. His wife has a grocery stall.

Benjamin sells crates of drinks at retail and wholesale prices. He has been in this business for 3 years. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs and necessities of his immediate family members.

He is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. He hopes to purchase a van in the future to enable him supply his crates of drinks by himself.

He says thanks to all his lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Reylene

texts.en:
44 year-old Reylene V. works hard to help her husband Herman meet their family's needs. Herman earns a living by driving a motorcycle and shuttling people around town for a fee.

Reylene appreciated how much her husband worked hard and sacrificed for their family but she knew that she had to contribute to their family income if she wanted her 2 children to have the opportunities that she aspired for them - to finish college and have stable jobs or be established in their own livelihoods.

She decided that a general store that sold a variety of household necessities would be a good business for her, and she was quite successful in this venture. 

But as the inventory turnover increased because of the higher demand for her goods, she realized that she had to get more capital because it was not practical or economical for her to replenish her inventory every time an item ran out of stock. 

She needed additional capital so that she could buy higher quantities of the items that are in high demand. This is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003.

With access to additional capital, she was able to increase her income capacity and slowly started to realize some of her dreams. She is now secure that she could afford her children's education and the monthly net income of 7,000 PHP from her business operations is a big help to making their life a little bit more comfortable. 

With this higher income she has been able to purchase 2 additional motorcycles so that it also earns an additional income for the family.

Reylene previously borrowed 25,000 PHP which she used as revolving capital for her general store. When she paid it off, she applied for a new loan, and now she wants to borrow 27,000 PHP so that she can sustain the optimum inventory levels in her general store, and also do repair and maintenance work on the motorcycles.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for general store & motorcycle repair.

loans.name: Ziyad

texts.en:
Ziyad is a Palestinian man living in the Al-Shiekh Radwan neighborhood in Gaza City. He is married with five children and the eldest is studying in the university.

Ziyad is an employee in the Palestinian National Authority in addition to owning this grocery store. He bought this store from his brother last year since he wanted to increase his income as he has a big family and most of them are still very young. In addition, his eldest son could help him in managing the store.

Ziyad requested 2,000 USD to buy more goods for his shop in order to have a variety of products to meet his customers’ requirements. He also wants to fix the motor of the freezer he has in the shop.

Ziyad appears in the photo at his store.

loans.use: To purchase more products for his grocery store

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida Y. is a 51 year old hard working mother and entrepreneur. She has been a member of ASHI for almost 5 years and received 7 loans, with good repayment performance. Leonida is still seeking bigger opportunities for her business and aims to have a good life and comfortable standard of living.

Leonida has 3 children; Jennifer a 28 year old who didn’t finish college, Janice a 27 years old, who still studies at college and Joann a 16 years old first year college student. Even at Leonida's older age, she still needs to support her children and provide them with education. Leonida is married to her good-looking and caring husband Edward Y., who is 54 years old and a company driver.

Leonida is seeking a loan of Php 40,000 to expand her business selling rice, sugar and balot penoy (a local specialty food). She will use half the money to purchase a tricycle for her business. Leonida asks for your helping hand to help her make her family's dreams and hopes come true.

loans.use: Purchase a tricycle and rice & sugar for business

loans.name: Touma

texts.en:
Touma J. is 28 years old and married with 2 children who both go to school. Her husband is a driver, and she is currently in the business of designing and selling bedsheets. Touma is requesting a loan to purchase more materials for this business and hopes to use her extra profits to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Materials for making and selling bedsheets

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 51 years old and married with 8 children. She sells provisions close to her home and is excited to receive a Kiva loan of 140, 000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 40 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and she runs a cooked food business which is growing by the day. With proceeds from this business, she is able to meet her family's needs. Doris' greatest joy in this business is that she does not need to sell on credit to her customers, as they pay in cash. Doris hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Lovelina

texts.en: Lovelina is 35 years old and married with six children who are all excelling in school. Her husband is a pastor and she makes and sells local soaps called 'soda'. She is very happy because she is able to make local soap that is highly demanded in her community in Benin City, Edo state. Lovelina hopes for a loan amount of 40,000 NGN to purchase more materials to make more local soaps to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make more local soaps to sell.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca L. is a 57 year-old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy. Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Her husband helps her run their business. They have one adult child.

Even if they don't have a big family to support, Rebecca continues working hard for her business because she wants to improve their living conditions and move their family out of poverty. She had always dreamed of improving their life which is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she wanted to start a general store, which she set up adjacent to her house.

The loans from NWTF-PD allowed her to expand her business faster than if she had no external source of capital. When her business had sufficiently improved, she diversified to other money-making ventures like a backyard pig-fattening project and a bakery.

Of all her businesses, the bakery gives Rebecca the most satisfaction because it enables her to help other people by providing employment opportunities to people in their community.

Her three business activities now earn a monthly income of 38,000 PHP and provide a comfortable living for their family of three.

In her previous loan, Rebecca borrowed 29,000 PHP which she used as additional capital for her general store, bakery and pig-fattening ventures. Having paid that loan in full, Rebecca now wants to borrow for her 15th loan cycle the same amount of 29,000 PHP to continue sustaining the operations of her bakery and the inventory levels of her general store.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her bakery and general store.

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu J. is 50 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.

Dudu is currently in the business of selling onions and fresh fish. She is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 29 years old, single, and has a primary school education. He has eight years of experience in his business and has one employee.

The purpose behind this loan is to purchase a new machine for his shop which will bring in more customers. He plans to hire more employees to help him, so as to deliver faster service to his clients.

loans.use: To purchase a new machine to fix punctures and change oil

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden J. is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school.

Kiden is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil to sell.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and to purchase a television for home use.

About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 32 years old, married, and has three children. He has schooling to the intermediate level. His wife has a salary of $400 monthly.

He worked for ten years as an assistant in this type of business. Six years ago he established his own shop so as to raise his family’s income. He has a good reputation in his community.

loans.use: To buy vinegar and to improve his decor

loans.name: Jenart

texts.en:
Jenart E. is 46 years old and married with 9 children. Her husband sells planks at retail prices to his customers. She cooks and sells fufu at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. Fufu comes from fermented cassava.

The demands for her fufu are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers.

Jenart hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cassava to cook more fufu to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava to cook more fufu to sell.

loans.name: Marco Antonio

texts.es:
El socio MARCO ANTONIO pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es original del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

El socio tiene 32 años de edad es soltero y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. El socio es diagramador (Editor de Noticias del periódico “El comercio”). Ya son cinco años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para poder invertir en un pequeño negocio de venta y mantenimientos de equipos de cómputo por esta navidad va comprar repuestos y accesorios para impresoras y computadoras. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Marco Antonio is a member of the community bank ‘Hatun Sonocco’. In the Quechua language, the word ‘hatun’ means ‘large’, and ‘sonocco’ means heart. So the bank’s name means ‘large heart’. Marco is 32 years old, single, and lives in city of Cusco. He has been a news editor with the newspaper El Comercio for five years, a job which has gone well thanks to the hard work that he has put in. Marco, a member of our bank, wants a loan so he can buy a small business selling and repairing computer equipment. This Christmas he plans to buy spare parts and accessories for printers and computers. Marco is grateful for this opportunity to borrow money, and he promises to pay back the loan installments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy accessories and spare parts for computer equipment

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en:
Ritchel T., her husband Johnel and their 3 young children live in Brgy. Biao, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. Ritchel is 29 years old and her 3 children are between 3 to 9 years old. Ritchel’s fondest hope is for her children to finish college and have good jobs or livelihoods when they grow up.

Ritchel realized early on that if they only relied on one source of income, she would probably not be able to fulfill her dreams for her children. She knew that she had the necessary skills to run a general store but she did not have the capital to even start one. When a friend informed her about how NWTF could help her, she immediately joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005.

Determined to make her new business a success, Ritchel worked hard to provide her customers with the items that they needed, and in the 4 years that she has been running the store, her monthly income has periodically increased.

Now she earns about 24,000 PHP per month from her business activities which includes selling specialty products to her neighbors. Her income from her business activities has enabled her to have their house fixed.

Because she wants to pay her loans off in the shortest possible time, she has always borrowed on short terms. She used her previous loan of 19,000 PHP as additional working capital for her business. Maintaining her good credit performance, she paid off that loan within its loan term, and this has enabled her to borrow a bigger loan for the next cycle. 

She is now borrowing 20,000 PHP for her 9th loan cycle so that she can sustain the inventory levels of her general store.

In the accompanying picture, Ritchel is at the back of her general store, which is attached to her house, with empty bottles waiting for the delivery van to pick up and replenish.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store.

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
Genoveva is 49 years old and is married to Sixto Zarate. They have 8 children, 7 of whom are independent and have their own families and the youngest is studying at school.

Genoveva opened a sewing and tailoring shop after working at a similar shop for many years. She started with one sewing machine and now has four. Her husband, Sixto, buys and sells cattle. Genoveva’s goal is to expand her business further, buy more machines and employ more people in her shop.

loans.use: Materials and fabrics

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella sells baby cream, clothes and hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. With these combined businesses, she sells for long hours to ensure that there is food on her table to feed her immediate family members. She is 43 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home.

She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more baby cream, clothes and hair extensions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby cream, clothes and hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Mrs. Nelly M. is a native of Barangay Palaka Norte, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. She is a 62 year-old widow with nephews that she has taken under her wing. She supports them in terms of food, education and their daily needs. At 62, she is happy and eager to help her family sustain their needs, especially in sending them to school, because she believes that sending them to school will equip her nephews in every challenge of life they will encounter. She has an adopted child who is also helping her in running her business. She started her business by selling condiments in their community until her business grew and later she considered selling vegetables. Now she has a block inside the local market place where she displays all her stock. As part of her business routine every week, she has a delivery of vegetables and spices, guaranteeing that she always sells fresh produce to her customers. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Celestino

texts.en:
Celestino M. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, beans and onions. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans and onions to sell. Celestino is 33 years old and is married to a a car driver. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and provide them with food.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of beans and onions to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is 25 years old, single, and has a primary school education. He has been working in this market for five years. Despite his youth he has a good reputation in the market and also he is an employee in a government office. His brother collaborates with him in his work.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and to redesign his market

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.en: Maria Cristina C. has been married to Francis Aquino for over ten years. Together, they have two sons, who now work abroad. She is a merchant and vendor and owns a food stall and canteen outside her home. She makes sufficient profits to help her cover the household expenses. Maria has been a client of the Foundacion Paraguaya since 2006. She has received loans for the renovation of her home and the purchase of merchandise and has always paid her loan back on time.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing sells beef in the market. She is a hard working woman and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to expand her business in the future by including the sales of turkeys to her beef business. She is 42 years old, married, and has a child. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more beef to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell.

loans.name: Rosa Jakeline

texts.es:
La socia ROSA JAKELINE pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es original del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

La socia tiene 25 años de edad es soltera y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia es profesora del nivel primario en el colegio “Niño Jesús” del Cusco, nuestra socia es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora pues con mucho anhelo abrió una pequeña librería.
