Ya tiene un año con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder aumentar el capital del negocio. Por estas fiestas navideñas quiere comprar y vender juguetes, arreglos navideños y peluches.     

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
ROSA JAKELINE is a client of the Community Bank “HATUN SONCCO”. The name of the community bank is from the Quechua language. "HATUN" means "Large" and "SONCCO" means "Heart", which translated into English means "Large Heart". Rosa is 25 years old, single, and lives in the imperial city of Cuzco. She is a first grade teacher in the “Niño Jesús (Baby Jesus)” school in Cuzco. She is a very hard worker, and very entrepreneurial, so she has very eagerly opened a small book store. She has done this for a year, and it has gone very well, due to the determination Rosa brings to her work. Rosa is requesting a loan to supplement her business capital. For the Christmas holidays who wants to purchase and sell toys, Christmas gifts and stuffed animals. Rosa is grateful for the opportunity offered in this way, and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital to sell Christmas gifts

loans.name: Nicasio Antonio

texts.es: Nicasio Antonio tiene la edad de 65 años, tiene 3 hijos y todos trabajan de manera independiente. El se dedica a la actividad económica de una pulpería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Por lo que inicio ofreciendo la venta de productos básicos como arroz, azúcar, aceite y frijoles. Por lo que el principal negocio de Nicasio es satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes ofreciéndoles lo que ellos solicitan. Es así como recurre a Fundación León 2000 ya que por medio ella las organizaciones amigas dan el apoyo necesario y solicita el financiamiento para capital de trabajo para granos básicos, golosinas, refrescos, gaseosas, bisutería y leche en bolsa. Su deseo es convertir su negocio en una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Nicasio Antonio is 65 years old and has 3 children, all of whom work independently. He devotes his time to running a small shop, which he has done for 5 years. Initially, he offered basic products such as rice, sugar, cooking oil and beans. Since Nicasio's main business is to satisfy the needs of his customers, he offers the items they request. This is why he has turned to Fundación León 2000, since through these organizations friends give each other needed support. He is requesting financing for working capital to purchase basic grains, sweets, soft drinks, sodas, trinkets and powdered milk. He hopes to convert his business and become a distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Business minded Teresita C. is 68 years old, a widow with three children, and has a small business. She sells different kinds of goods (Sari Sari Store) for the daily needs of their neighbors. 

Due to poverty, her eldest child, Jose, as well as her youngest, Reynaldo, finished only high school. Teresita has been a member of ASHI for 2 years now and has been engaged in her small business for almost 6 years. 

ASHI has been a big support for her small business and she dreams that her small business will grow bigger by the time of her retirement so that she can enjoy her good old life. She also wants to provide more goods to serve her neighborhood, and this is why she continues taking out loans from ASHI so that her sari-sari store can become a grocery store. ASHI (Kiva field partner) has been a great help for her family because they can now support their daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase different goods for her general store.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose G. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Rose is 30 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria where she sells sarongs at the market. She is 57 years old and married with 7 children. Rose would like to get a loan to purchase additional sarongs for the season. She is planning to purchase a variety of sarongs and will significantly expand her sarong business. Rose believes that having an assortment of good-quality sarongs will increase her sales. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
Maria Trinidad T. de 47 años, conjuntamente con su esposo elaboran joyas desde hace más de 20 años, compran la materia prima de una distribuidora que se encuentra en la Ceja de la Ciudad de El Alto  y venden sus productos en la feria 16 de Julio, también  en Cochabamba, Sucre, Potosí y Oruro, con esta actividad económica María y su esposo han podido sacar adelante a su numerosa familia ya que tienen 10 hijos, en la actualidad 6 están bajo el cuidado de ellos y 4 son independientes. En esta oportunidad Maria y su esposo necesitan el  préstamo para  comprar piedras finas y seguir elaborando sus productos.
Renacer que pertenece al Centro Focal German Busch tiene 8 integrantes  con diversas actividades económicas, así dos de ellas se dedican a la cerrajería,  otras cuatro al tejido de prendas de vestir como polainas y chompas,  una vende CDS y por último Maria elabora joyas. Todas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería o materia prima según el negocio que tengan.
texts.en:
María Trinidad T. is 47 and has made jewelry with her husband for more than 20 years. They buy supplies from a distributor in La Ceja in the city of El Alto and sell their products in the 16 de Julio market. They also sell in Cochabamba, Sucre, Potosí, and Oruro. With this activity, María and her husband have been able to take care of their large family. They have 10 kids: 6 are under their care and 4 are independent. María and her husband need this loan to be able to buy fine stones so they can keep making their products. The Renacer group belongs to the German Busch center and has 8 members with diverse economic activities. Two of them work as locksmiths, four others weave garments like leg warmers and sweaters, one sells CDs, and María makes jewelry. All of them need this loan to buy merchandise or materials according to the needs of the business they have.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise and supplies (fine stones)

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: She is 27 years old, married and has one kid. Her spouse is an employee also. At the beginning she worked as an employee in the most famous beauty shop in the city. Later she wished to open a shop for herself in order to be able to keep her earnings. 4 years ago she was capable of opening this shop for herself. She has a high reputation in the market.

loans.use: For Purchasing Cosmetics

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: T. K. Martine est née le 31 Janvier 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Martine vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, depuis 11 ans environs. Martine est mariée à LOKOSSOU Rodrigue, un agent à l’OPT, et est mère de quatre enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Martine n’a fait que le cours primaire à l’école. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Martine vend des biscuits et divers amuses  gueule à l’Ecole Primaire Publique de Cadjèhoun. Martine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bien remboursé les deux crédits qu’elle a reçus de ALIDé. C’est dans l’optique d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir son activité, que Martine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de l’institution.
texts.en:
T. K. Martine was born on January 31, 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been living in the Cadjèhoun district of Cotonou for about eleven years. She is married to LOKOSSOU Rodrigue, an agent at OPT, and is the mother of four children. All of the children are in school and live with their parents. The couple provides for the family jointly. Martine went to primary school only. For twelve years, she has been selling cookies and a variety of tasty snacks at the Ecole Primaire Publique de Cadjèhoun. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repaid the two loans she received from ALIDé. With regard to augmenting her working capital and expanding her business, she's requesting a third loan from this micro-finance institution.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Boxes of cookies and tasty snacks

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en: Kenneth is 42 years old and married with 3 children. His wife sells medicines in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. He is a commercial motorcyclist. He has been in this business for a year.  He hopes to own a transport company in the future.  He is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase one motorcycle. He works long hours to ensure that he is able to meet the basic needs of his family. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria R. is currently in the business of selling ground-nut paste from her home. Victoria is 27 years old and married.  Her husband is a butcher. She has one child, who is in school.  Victoria is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of ground-nuts to make into paste to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.
 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more bags of ground-nuts to make into paste to sell

loans.name: Mernie

texts.en:
Her father always told her that hard work, dedication and being responsible would lead to financial independence and a comfortable life. Mernie A., who is now 46, has always followed this wise counsel. Her husband Joeffrey is a farmer and also helps her run her business.  They live in Purok Mabinuligon, Brgy. Busay, Bago City, Negros Occidental with their 6 children, aged 14 to 25. One of their children already has a family, the 2 youngest are still in school, and the rest are working to help the family improve their lot. Mernie hopes that her business will continue to prosper so that she can earn enough to send her younger children to college and also to invest in other business ventures so that they can increase their family income.

As a mother who went through a lot of sacrifices while she was growing up because her family was very poor, Mernie does not want her children to go through the same difficulties of having to earn a living just to help support the family. When she got married, she decided to start her own business by opening a general store. She also raised livestock like pigs and ducks in her backyard, but she stopped this at some point because she needed to revolve her capital faster, and so decided to concentrate on expanding her general store operations.

In 2001, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access the necessary capital to expand and diversify her business. As the years passed and she continued to maintain her good credit record, her loans allowed her to sell rice and eggs in addition to her general store. From her business income she was able to buy a small plot of land to grow rice. From her business activities she is able to earn a monthly income of PHP 4,000.

Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 was used as additional working capital for her general store and rice business. She was able to repay this amount on time within her loan term. Now she is borrowing PHP 19,500 as additional working capital for her general store and rice business.  This will be her 18th loan. She intends to save some of the additional income for the education of her children, and use some to buy piglets to raise to expand her business.
 
About NWTF:
  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for general store

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.en: The Mujeres Unidas Committee uses their loan to purchase clothing, beverages, meats, sausages, breads, herb, oil, sweets, vegetables, fruits, baked goods, confectionery, dairy, haberdashery, sewing items, yarns, fabrics, scissors, clothes, vegetables, fruit, and cleaning supplies.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: He is 24 years old, single, Assistant Accountant to the Notary Public  in the morning shift. He opened this shop 5 years ago. This is the 3rd loan that he has received from AL-Thiqa. He has made all the repayments in a timely manner. He has a single employee in his shop to work with him. He has a high income due to this shop because his shop has a good location in the market.

loans.use: For purchasing shoes

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.es:
La socia GUMERCINDA pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es original del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

La socia tiene 51 años de edad es casada, tienes 6 hijos y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia tiene un pequeño cafetín en el Instituto “Arco Iris”, nuestra socia es una mujer cariñosa, amable y emprendedora pues con mucho anhelo abrió el cafetín a tendiendo a jóvenes entres 16 y 24 años de edad. Ya son seis años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder aumentar el capital del negocio comprando panecillos, panetones y dulces navideños.            

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
GUMERCINDA is a client of the community bank “HATUN SONCCO”. The name of the community bank comes from the Quechua language. "HATUN" means "Large" and "SONCCO" means "Heart", which translated into English means "Large heart".

Gumercinda is 51 years old, married, and has 6 children. She lives in the imperial city of Cuzco. Gumercinda has a small cafe in the "Arco Iris (Rainbow)" Institute. She is a very caring woman, friendly and enterprising, and with a great deal of eagerness she opened her cafe, serving young people between the ages of 16 and 24. She has been doing this work for 6 years, and it has gone very well, due to the determination she brings to her work. Gumercinda is requesting a loan in order to supplement her working capital to purchase bread rolls, fruit cakes and Christmas candy.

Gumercinda appreciates the opportunity offered in this way, and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital to purchase bread rolls, fruit cakes and Christmas candy.

loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr: S. Victoire est née vers 1961 à Dogbo au Bénin. Victoire réside depuis environs 18 ans au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à SESSOU Richard un cuisinier, Victoire est mère de six enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Victoire vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Seul le mari assure les charges de la famille. Victoire n’a pas été à l’école. C’est depuis 18 ans que Victoire vend des céréales (riz, maïs, haricot blanc et rouge, etc.) en face de l’Ecole Primaire Publique de Cadjèhoun. Victoire mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de citron et de sachets. Victoire s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Adja au Mono au Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue d’accroître le revenu de son activité et de l’grandir davantage, Victoire sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Victoire envisage plus tard, acquérir sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
S. Victoire was born around 1961 in Dogbo in Benin. She has been residing for eighteen years in the Cadjèhoun district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to SESSOU Richard, a cook, she is the mother of six children who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband. The husband alone ensures that family expenses are covered. Victoire did not go to school. For eighteen years, she has been selling grains (rice, corn, white and red beans, etc.) opposite the Ecole Primaire Publique de Cadjèhoun. She runs a secondary business selling lemons and baggies. She stocks up on supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and in Adja in Mono, in Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans. With the aim of growing her business revenues and expanding her business further, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Victoire envisions acquiring her own parcel of land later on.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grains (sacks of rice, beans, and corn)

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells fruits and yams. The demand for her fruits is high and she hopes to meet this demand of her customers. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fruits to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local beer and is requesting a loan to puchase more materials to use. Mary is 26 years old and is married to a retired soldier. She has 1 child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To puchase more materials.

loans.name: Georgina Denise

texts.fr: A. Georgina Denise est née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est depuis près de 16 ans que Georgina Denise vit à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. Mariée à TCHIAKPE Victorin, Georgina Denise est mère de quatre enfants. Un autre enfant est à sa charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Georgina Denise vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son conjoint. Georgina Denise a fait seulement le cours primaire à l’école. Depuis près de 15 ans, Georgina Denise fait des jus, du yaourt, du Dèguè (yaourt fait à base du mil, sucre, lait, etc.) et les vend à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Georgina Denise s’approvisionne. Georgina Denise est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. C’est pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle que Georgina Denise sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Georgina Denise was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. For sixteen years, she has been living in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou. Married to TCHIAKPE Victorin, she is the mother of four children. And she supports another child. The children are all in school. She lives with her children and husband. Georgina Denise has gone to primary school only. For fifteen years, she has been making juices, yoghurt, and Dèguè (yoghurt made with millet, sugar, milk, etc.) She sells them out of her home. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she gets her supplies. She is a previous ALIDé client who has already obtained two loans from the micro-finance institution, and they have been repaid. To augment her working capital and to satisfy her customers more, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Boxes of sugar, powdered milk, and baggies

loans.name: Georgita

texts.en:
Expand her business, earn a good living, improve family living conditions and be able to send their children to school and finish their studies -- these are the main concerns of Georgita F., 43 years old, and her husband Leonardo. They are blessed with 3 young school-aged children. The family lives in the Prk. Waling, Waling Brgy, Busay Bago City, Negros Occidental. 

Georgita has a general store, a rice business, and also sells gasoline to earn additional income to help her husband sustain the needs of the family and meet their dreams in life. She started her business when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001, because she knew that if her husband alone had to generate all of the family's income, it might be too much pressure on him.  She was even worried that their children would not be able to finish their studies. But through their cooperative efforts, she and her husband are reaching for their dreams, but helping each other support their family. Now she earns a minimum monthly income of PHP 6,000, a portion of which she sets aside for the education of their children.

She borrowed PHP 8,000 with her previous loan, and used it as additional capital for her general store and other businesses. She was able to earn and repay her loan every week without delay and she was able to fully pay her loan within term. Now, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 to be used as additional working capital for her businesses. The income from it will be invested in expanding their business and to invest in the buying and selling of eggs. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital for her general store.

loans.name: Rosa Mistica Group

texts.en:
The Rosa Mistica Women’s Committee uses their loan to buy t-shirts, jackets, trousers, blouses, ingredients for pastries and baked goods, vegetables, napkins, yarn, fabrics, jewelry, herbs, milk, vegetables, coal, sugar, flour, herbs, candy, oil, gas, cosmetics, fruit, ladies' underwear, etc. 

The Committee was formed by several women who took the initiative to organize a group of women to work together to improve their livelihoods and businesses. Currently the committee is in the second cycle of the program and is comprised of 18 members who invest their loans in their independent business ventures.

Myrian V. sells clothing. 
Tania O. sells clothing.
Hilda E. sells vegetables and other grocery items. 
Eliodoro V. has a sewing workshop and is using her loan to purchase fabric and yarn for the manufacture of garments.
Wilma F. is dedicated to selling dry goods from a street stall. 
Jorgelina R. sells vegetables and other grocery items.
Mirta A. is devoted to selling cosmetics and beauty products.
Rosa M. sells medicinal herbs and remedies. 
Nidia Muñoz is dedicated to the sale of bijouterie and will use her loan to buy higher quality jewelry for her stock. 
Mirta A. has a pantry.
Cynthia A. sells sweets and invested the money in buying wholesale candy for sale.
Matilda B. sells fruits and is using the loan to buy more fruit to sell. 
Ernestina A. sells vegetables and other grocery items.
Natalia D. sells lingerie and invested the money in buying ladies' undergarments. 
Mary C. is dedicated to the sale of bijouterie and will use her loan to buy higher quality jewelry for her stock. 
Mrs. Sandra E. sells lingerie and invested the money in buying ladies' undergarments for later sale.
Gloria A. sells vegetables and other grocery items.
Mrs. Susana A. sells sweets and invested the money in buying wholesale products for sale.
Mirian R. sells lingerie and invested the money in buying ladies' undergarments.
Liliana D. sells vegetables and other grocery items.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia J. is currently in the business of selling beer and local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Lucia is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar in the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: Maritza M. es casada, tiene 2 hijos: el mayor de 9 años, estudia 3er grado de educación primaria y la niña menor de de seis años de edad estudia 1er grado,su su esposo labora como albañil y asume los gastos del hogar, Maritza labora en  el INSS de  Nueva Guinea desde  hace 9 años, está solicitando  su 4to refinanciamiento para invertirlo en  mejora de su vivienda construyendo una habitación en la casa,  actualmente esta estudiando su primer año de Administración de Empresas en la Universidad URACCAN,  esta joven se caracteriza por ser humilde, responsable, honesta y con muncho deseos de superación personal, viven en la zona # 5 de Nueva Guinea, en un barrio creciente, su sueño es tener estabilidad laboral, una vivienda bonita y que sus hijos estudien para que sean personas de bien.
texts.en:
Maritza M. is married, and has 2 children: the oldest is 9 years old and in 3rd grade, and the youngest is 6 years old and in 1st grade. Her husband works as a bricklayer and earns money for their home expenses. Maritza has worked in the INSS (Nicaragua Social Security Institute) in Nueva Guinea for 9 years. She is requesting her 4th loan to put towards renovating and building an additional bedroom on her house. Currently, whe is in her first year of studies in Business Administration in the University URACCAN. This young woman is humble, responsible, honest and has great desire to improve herself. She lives in Zone 5 of Nueva Guinea, in a growing neighborhood. Her dream is to have stable work, a pretty home and that her children study and become good people.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a home addition

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: A. Béatrice est née vers 1937 à Abomey, ville historique du Bénin. C’est une veuve qui vit depuis près de 40 ans au quartier Cadjèhoun, capitale économique du Bénin. Béatrice est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et qui ne sont plus à sa charge. Béatrice vit seule. C’est une analphabète qui mène depuis près de 10 ans, la vente de yaourt (fait à base de lait en poudre, du sucre, etc.), de jus de fruits et de glaces à son domicile, afin de subvenir à ses besoins. Béatrice s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Béatrice sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de produire plus de yaourt et de glace pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
AKINDES Georgina Denise was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. For sixteen years, she has been living in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou. Married to TCHIAKPE Victorin, she is the mother of four children. And she supports another child. The children are all in school. She lives with her children and husband. Georgina Denise has gone to primary school only. For fifteen years, she has been making juices, yoghurt, andDèguè (yoghurt made with millet, sugar, milk, etc.) She sells them out of her home. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she gets her supplies. She is a previous ALIDé client who has already obtained two loans from the micro-finance institution, and they have been repaid. To augment her working capital and to satisfy her customers more, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Powdered milk, boxes of sugar, and baggies

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther sells garri (cassava flakes) at retail prices to her customers in the market. She is a focused, hard worker. She hopes to be a garri distributor in the future. She is 44 years old and married, with 5 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the family. She hopes for a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more garri to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more garri to sell

loans.name: Gloria Petrona

texts.es: Gloria Petrona tiene 57 años, es una mujer muy luchadora y le gusta muchos su trabajo. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general, hace más de 20 años inicio esta actividad porque anteriormente ella impartía clases en un colegio público, ya que ella empezó a llevar ciertos productos para ofrecerlos a sus compañeros de trabajo, por lo que esto le dio la iniciativa de salir adelante con esta fuente de ingresos. Todos su créditos han sido han sido aprovechados para su negocio. Actualmente ella solicita este financiamiento con el fin de invertir en más productos. Su deseo es engrandecer su negocio para mejorar su fuente de ingreso.
texts.en:
Gloria Petrona is 57 years old. She is very hard working and loves to work. Her business is the sale of general merchandise, which she has done for more than 20 years, before which she taught classes in a public school. She began by carrying certain products to offer to her co-workers, and this gave her the intiative to move ahead with this source of income. All of her business loans have been approved. Currently, Gloria is requesting financing to invest in more inventory. She hopes to increase her business and improve her source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose S. is currently in the business of selling beer and local alcohol in a bar.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell.  Rose is 28 years old and married; her husband is a car driver. She has 4 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and pay school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
La socia MARUJA pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es original del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

La socia tiene 47 años de edad, es casada, tiene 3 hijos; dos varones y una mujer y viven en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco, nuestra socia es docente en el nivel primario en la provincia de Acomayo, hace 20 años que se dedica a la enseñanza de niños de las zonas rurales. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el pequeño negocio de venta de pollos, nuestra socia es una mujer amable y emprendedora pues con mucha voluntad se dedica a la crianza y venta de pollos. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder comprar alimento balanceado para los pollos. 
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Maruja belongs to the Hatun Soncco Communal Bank. The name for the communal bank comes from the Quechua language. “Hatun” means big, and “Soncco” means heart. Translated into Spanish it means Big Heart. She is 47, married, and has three children; two boys and a girl. They live in the Imperial city of Cusco. She is an elementary school teacher in the Acomayo province. She has been teaching children in the rural areas for 20 years. She alternates her activities between the household and her small chicken selling business. She is a very kind and enterprising woman. She devotes herself to raising and selling chickens with much joy. She has been doing this for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy balanced food for her chickens. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy balanced food for the chickens she sells

loans.name: Lawranta

texts.en: Lawranta sells soup ingredients like crayfish, dry pepper and cooking oil at retail prices to her customers in the market. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She is 45 years old and married, with 5 children. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to  purchase more soup ingredients to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Sikiratou

texts.fr: Z. Sikiratou est née vers 1960 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à DAHOUNDO Luc, un agent à l’Office des Postes et Télécommunication (OPT) au Bénin, Sikiratou est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Sikiratou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. C’est depuis une quinzaine d’année que Sikiratou vit dans ce quartier. Sikiratou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Sikiratou n’a fait que le cours primaire à l’école. Il y a 10 ans de cela que Sikiratou mène comme activité, la vente de « Akpan » (bouillie locale faite à base d’amidon de maïs, accompagnée de sucre et de lait) et du pain sucré à la devanture de sa maison. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Sikiratou fait ses emplettes. Sikiratou a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Afin d’augmenter le volume de son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Sikiratou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Z. Sikiratou was born around 1960 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to DAHOUNDO Luc, an agent at the Office des Postes et Télécommunication (OPT) in Benin, she is the mother of five children who are all in school.  She lives together with her children and husband in the Cadjèhoun district in Cotonou and has lived in this district for fifteen years.  She works in aid of her husband to cover family expenses.  Sikiratou attended primary school only.  For ten years, she has been in the business of selling akpan (a local porridge made with corn starch served with sugar and milk) and sweetened breads, at the entrance to her house.  She makes her purchases at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already benefited from two ALIDé loans, which were repaid.  To increase her business volume and to satisfy her customers further, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sacks of corn, boxes of sugar, and baskets of sweetened breads

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
50-year-old Melanie T. lives in Hda. Panaogao Marland, Brgy IV, Silay City, Negros Occidental. Her husband Anselmo works as a laborer in Hacienda on a sugar-cane plantation.  He earns a minimum salary that depends on the time of year:  during sugar milling season, he works six days a week, but during the off-season he works only three to four days a week. The couple is blessed with four children, ages 21 to 27. They work and contribute to help support the household. Melanie dreams of improving their living, fixing their house, buying productive assets and saving enough to support herself and her husband when they grow old.

She knew that all these dreams would be for naught if she stayed at home and just waited for her husband to hand her his meager salary. She saved enough from her husband's salary to start a small general store selling only the most in-demand household commodities. When she realized that she needed additional capital to sustain her growing business, it was timely that she heard about the microcredit services of NWTF-Project Dungganon. She became a member in 2004 and from that point on, she never looked back but continued to expand and diversify her business activities. Today, in addition to her general store, she has a rice retailing business where most of her customers are the laborers who work on the sugar-cane plantation where they live. They get the rice on credit for their daily needs and pay back at the end of the week when they receive their salary. She has also put up a barbecue stand. She earns a cumulative net profit of PHP 4,400 per month.

Her previous loan of PHP 9,500 was used as additional working capital for her businesses. The loan was fully repaid without delay. Now she is borrowing PHP 19,500 to be used in her general store and for her rice retailing business. She needs this higher capital because sugar milling season has already started and she anticipates a higher demand for all her goods. She will use the income to repair her house and to buy productive assets to be used in her businesses.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store and rice retailling business

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa de Jesús G. de 48 años de edad, reside en Colón en el departamento de la Libertad, vive junto a sus dos hijos menores de edad, los cuales depende únicamente de ella. Teresa posee una venta de ropa en las afueras del mercado de Santa Tecla y en el vende ropa para niños y adultos de ambos sexos. Ella solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar  más ropa, ya que desea aprovechar la temporada navideña, esperando aumentar sus ventas y poder brindarles todo lo mejor a sus hijos, sobre todo en esta temporada de fin de año.
texts.en:
Teresa de Jesús G., 48, lives in Colón in the Libertad department. She lives with her two minor children. They are dependent solely upon her. Teresa has a business selling clothes on the outskirts of the Santa Tecla Market. She sells clothing for children and adults of both sexes. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy more clothes. She wants to take advantage of the Christmas season. She is hoping to increase her sales to be able to give her children the best, especially in this season at the end of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more clothes

loans.name: Virgen De Las Mercedes Group

texts.en:
The Women's Committee of the Virgen de Las Mercedes Las Mercedes was formed by a group of entrepreneurial women who invited their neighbors and friends to form a new group. Currently the committee has 22 members, all of whom invest their loans in independent businesses. 

The Virgen de las Mercedes committee will use their loan to buy T-shirts, jackets, trousers, blouses, candy, meats, ingredients for pastries and baked goods, vegetables, napkins, coal, oil, rice, sugar, flour, pasta, soda, beer, clay, paints, molds for pottery, creams, shampoo, silver jewelry, ice cream, etc.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Physical imperfection is not the hindrance to success, this makes oneself feel proud because she did what other normal people can do. That’s Ma. Elena H., who, despite her physical imperfection, tries to help her husband and family improve their living conditions. She is 49 years old, married to Rogelio, who works as a sugarcane supervisor. She has two children aged 22 and 28 years old. The family lives in Hacienda Cosolacion, Silay City, Negros Occidental.

To help her family earn additional income, Ma. Elena invested in a pig fattening Business, which she managed with the help of her children. Because she wants to add more piglets to her business, she decided to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 to access more capital. The loans that she received since then have been used to buy additional piglets, feed, and vitamins for her pigs. Her loans helped to sustain her business and has enabled her to earn PHP 10,000 every time she sells her pigs, which takes 3-4 months to raise. She uses the income to support her children's needs and their household expenses. She is very happy that despite her situation she could earn an income and help her family.

Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 was utilized for her pig fattening business and the amount was fully paid on time without delay. Now she is borrowing PHP 9,000 for her 15th cycle loan to use to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Any profits will be used to defray family expenses.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase adiitional feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.fr: M. Rosalie est née le 04 Septembre 1965 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rosalie est mariée à KPAMEGAN Pamphile, un agent à l’OCBN au Bénin, et est mère de trois enfants, dont un est à sa charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. C’est depuis 14 ans que Rosalie vit au Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. Rosalie vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Pour cela, il y a deux ans, Rosalie  vend des jus de bissap et aussi des boissons à son domicile. C’est dans les dépôts de vente de boissons que Rosalie fait ses approvisionnements. Rosalie est à son quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les trois crédits précédents que Rosalie a obtenus auprès de ALIDé ont été bien remboursés.  Rosalie sollicite ce quatrième crédit afin d’augmenter le stock de produits et de satisfaire davantage les besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
M. Rosalie was born on September 4, 1965 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She is married to KPAMEGAN Pamphile, an OCBN agent in Benin, and she is the mother of three children, one of whom is in her care.   The children are all in school and live together with their parents.  For fourteen years, she has lived in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou.  She works in aid of her husband to cover family expenses.  To do so, she has been selling bissap juice and also drinks out of her home for two years.  She stocks up from sales outlets which sell beverages.  Rosalie is on her fourth ALIDé loan.  The three preceding ones that she obtained from ALIDé were repaid.  She's requesting this fourth loan in order to increase her stock of merchandise and to satisfy further the needs of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Beverages (non-alcoholic and fruit juices)

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma P. lives in the village of Pader Aguisan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She is 43 years old. Her husband, Rene, works as a fisherman and sometimes as a carpenter. She has three children who are between 11 and 16 years old and they are all presently studying. This couple help each other provide a better future for their children by sending them to school so that they can get a proper education and be able to improve their living conditions. They also work hard because they want to provide a comfortable life for their youngest daughter who has special needs. They plan to send her to Bacolod for special education.

Alma decided to start a business because she saw that her husband's income was not secure, and she was afraid that if she couldn’t help her husband by earning even a little income, maybe someday they would not be able to afford the education of their children and not have a stable future. This is the reason she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 – so that she could access much needed capital to put up a general store and have an independent income. As her income capacity increased, she started selling vinegar and later frozen products, earning a good income. Her businesses now earns her 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month. She saves most of her profit for the education of her older children and medication for her special child.

Alma's previous loan of 19,000 PHP was used as additional working capital for her general store. It was fully repaid without delay and now she wants to borrow 19,500 PHP (her ninth loan) to buy a refrigerator for her general store for the frozen products she sells.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for her general store

loans.name: Gladys Njeri

texts.en:
Gladys Njeri is a 36 year old enterprising mother of three aged 11, 8 and 4. She is married to Joseph Omondi. She has been operating a poultry business for the last 5 years. She currenly has forty chickens used for laying and fifty used for slaughtering and selling. She has established contacts with cafe owners in Kisumu City, who provide a steady demand for her eggs and poultry meat.

Gladys also has one rental house she has developed with income derived from the poultry business. She expects to construct three more in the next three years, to enable her to pay school fees comfortably for her first son, who will then have joined high school.

This is her fifth loan from KADET Ltd and she intends to use the funds to purchase more poultry feed and some building materials for furnishing a rental house she had constructed. Gladys was introduced to KADET Ltd by her aunt, who was an existing customer of KADET Ltd.

She aspires to own many rental houses because she feels that would be a better guarantee for regular income.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed and building materials for her poultry business.

loans.name: Nicolas De Tolentino

texts.es: Don Nicolas está solicitando su primer crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (Repellar la vivienda), trabaja como Guardia de Seguridad  desde hace 3 años en la Universidad, tiene dos hijos los que actualmente los tiene estudiando su primaria, su esposa se encarga de los quehaceres del hogar y del cuidos de los dos hijos,viven en la zona urbana de Nueva Guinea, el es un hombre  con alto espiritud de superación personal ,  responsable,  que ama su trabajo,  su sueño  es que sus hijos estudien  para que lleguen hacer unos excelentes profesionales y   tener estabilidad laboral, salud, una vivienda  bonita,  solicitamos al comité de crédito  se le apruebe el monto solicitado.
texts.en:
Nicolas is asking for his first loan to make improvements on his house (plaster the house). He has worked as a security guard for the university for three years. He has two children who are currently in elementary school. His wife takes care of the household chores, and she takes care of their two children. He is a man with a lot of spirit for personal success. He is responsible and loves his work. His dream is that his children study and become excellent professionals with work stability, health, and a nice home. We are asking the loan committee to approve the solicited amount.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plaster his house

loans.name: Claire

texts.fr: H. Claire est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Claire réside depuis sa naissance au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. C’est une veuve qui est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Claire a un autre enfant à sa charge, en plus de ses enfants. Claire vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Claire n’a fait que le cours primaire à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Claire vend des condiments de sauce (tomates fraîche et en boîte, oignons, piments, gingembre, poivre, cube, etc.) et aussi de l’huile de palme au marché de Gbégamey à Cotonou. C’est dans ce même marché que Claire s’approvisionne. Claire a 15 ans d’expérience dans cette activité. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a eu déjà deux crédits auprès de l’institution et dont les remboursements se sont bien passés. Claire sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’accroître son activité et de satisfaire la demande de la clientèle au cours de la période de préparation des fêtes.
texts.en:
H. Claire was born on 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Since birth, she has been residing in the Cadjèhoun district in Cotonou.  She is a widow and the mother of two children who are both in school.  She has another child to support in addition to her own.  She lives alone with her children and is the only one supporting the family.  Claire has attended primary school only.  To provide for herself, she sells sauce condiments (fresh and canned tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, ginger, black pepper, bouillon cubes, etc.) and also palm oil at the Gbégamey market in Cotonou. She gets her supplies from the same market.  She has fifteen years of experience in this business. She is a previous ALIDé client who already had two loans from this micro-finance institution, and the repayments went well.  She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé in order to grow her business and to satisfy customer demands during preparations for this holiday period. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sauce condiments (baskets of fresh tomatoes, chili peppers, and onions)

loans.name: Celestina

texts.es:
Celestina tiene 39 años, vive con su esposo, Demetrio, y con sus 2 hijos: Leslie de 16 y Elvis de 14, en su casa propia.

Desde hace 2 años tiene una tienda de abarrotes y verduras, la cual funciona en su vivienda, así le da tiempo para obtener ingresos económicos sin descuidar la atención de sus hijos, ya que puede atenderlos por la mañana y cuando retornan del colegio.
Su  esposo trabaja vendiendo baterías y juntos se han propuesto darles educación universitaria a sus hijos, por ello luchan de sol a sol para cumplir con sus objetivos. El negocio va prosperando y gracias a su buena atención, Celestina está logrando captar buena cantidad de clientes.
Sus planes a futuro son de tener mini market, realizando su sueño y el de sus hijos, de ser unos buenos profesionales.  

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, sus compañeros de grupo confían en ella porque es muy responsable en todos sus actos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más mercadería para abastecer su tienda y esté más surtida.
texts.en:
Celestina is 39 years old, and lives with her husband, Demetrio, and their 2 children, Leslie, 16 and Elvis, 14, in their own home.

For 2 years Celestina has had a shop where she sells groceries and produce out of her home, as this gives her the opportunity to make an income without neglecting the care of her children, since she can tend to them in the morning and after school.

Her husband works selling batteries, and together they are trying to provide their children with a college education. They work from sunrise to sundown to achieve their goals. The business has prospered and, thanks to Celestina's attentiveness, has acquired a large number of customers. Celestina's future plans are to have a mini-market, realizing her dream and that of her children, to become professionals.

This is Celestina's first loan with MFP. The partners in her group trust her because she is very responsible in all she does. With the money she is requesting, she will purchase more merchandise to supply her store and be fully stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria tiene 48 años, vive con su pareja (Alfonso), de 48 años, y con sus 3 hijos: Alfonso de 25, Carlos de 23 y Luis Ángel de 9 años, en su casa propia.

Ella se dedica a la atención de su Librería bazar, la cual se encuentra en su propio domicilio, dándole la facilidad de atender a sus hijos y a la vez generarse buenos ingresos. A ella le gusta mucho su trabajo, pues es tranquilo y siempre tiene mucha clientela, la cual aparte de comprar se queda conversando con ella, debido a que doña Gloria es muy amistosa con todas las personas.
Su carisma ha logrado que todos en su vecindario le tengan aprecio y por ende la visitan más frecuentemente para comprar los artículos que ofrece, además su librería está muy bien surtida.
Para el futuro, Gloria quiere mejorar e implementar mejor le área de su mini bazar, ya que ha notado que estos artículos (adornos, juguetes, accesorios personales) tienen gran demanda.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, ella es muy responsable en su negocio y por ende promete serlo también en los pagos de sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad mercadería en cuadernos, pues ya se le están acabando y son muy demandados, además de los artículos para su bazar.
texts.en:
Gloria is 48 years old, and lives with her partner (Alfonso), also 48 years old, and their 3 children, Alfonso, 25, Carlos, 23 and Luis Angel,9, in their own home.

Gloria devotes her attention to her book shop/bazaar, which she runs out of her home, allowing her to take care of her children while earning a good income. Gloria loves her work, because it is calm and she always has lots of customers, who in addition to buying stay and talk with Gloria, since she is very friendly with everyone. Her charisma has given her whole neighborhood an appreciation for her, and they visit frequently to buy the items she offers, as her shop is well stocked. For the future, Gloria would like to improve and expand the area her mini-bazaar occupies, since she has noticed that these items (decorations, toys, personal accessories) are in great demand.

This is Gloria's first loan with MFP. She is very responsible with her business and promises to make all her payments on time. With the money she is requesting, Gloria will purchase greater quantities of notebooks, since she is running out and they are very popular, as well as other articles for teh bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana es una mujer muy trabajadora de 47 años, vive con su esposo (Guillermo), de 48 años, y con sus 6 hijos: María de 20, Elmer de 19, Rosa de 16, Jonatan de 15, Jordan de 10 y Jerson de 4 añitos de edad. Todos ellos son muy unidos y gracias a tanto esfuerzo adquirieron su casa propia.

Ella se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, actividad que realiza desde algunos años para obtener un ingreso extra al sueldo de su esposo, quien trabaja como albañil. A Juana le gusta mucho su trabajo, puesto que le permite tener libertad en cuanto a su economía y además puede pasar tiempo con sus hijos, los cuales son muy dependientes de ella porque la quieren mucho. Para su negocio no tiene un horario, visita a sus clientes durante sus tiempos libres y otras veces sus amigas van a su casa para pedirle sus productos y ver sus catálogos.
Juana tiene mucha paciencia para atender a las personas, es por eso que sus clientes la recomiendas con otras personas y así va obteniendo más pedidos, además de que los productos de la línea de belleza que ofrece son de muy buena calidad.
Para el futuro, quiere tener un bazar en su casa donde pueda mostrar mejor sus cosméticos y vender otros artículos.

Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y promete ser muy responsable y puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad de productos para tener en stock y poder ofrecer de manera inmediata, sin esperar hacer la solicitud por medio del catálogo.
texts.en:
Juana is a very hard-working 47 year old woman. She lives with her husband (Guillermo), 48 years old, and their 6 children, Maria, 20, Elmer, 19, Rosa, 16, Jonatan, 15, Jordan, 10 and Jerson, 4 years old. They are all very close and thanks to their great efforts have their own home.

Juana devotes herself to the sale of beauty products, an activity she has carried out for several years in order to earn income in addition to that of her husband, who works as a mason. Juana enjoys working, as it gives her financial freedom and allows her to spend time with her children, who are very dependent on her because they lover her very much. Her business does not have set hours. Juana visits her customers during her free time, and sometimes her friends come to her house to buy products and look at her catalogues. Juana is very patient in attending to her custumers, so they recommend her to other people and in this way she acquires more orders. In addition, the beauty products she offers are very high quality. In the future, Juana wants to have a shop in her house where she can better display her cosmetics and sell other items.

This is Juana's first loan with MFP, and she promises to be very responsible and punctual with her payments. With the money she is requesting, Juana will purchase a larger quantity of products to have in stock, so she can offer these immediately to her customers, without having to wait for a catalogue order.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Karla Elisa

texts.es: La Señora  Karla Elisa tiene 32 años, tiene 1 hijo y estudia su edad es de 5 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, surgió por la necesidad de obtener ingresos para su familia, y quien la ayudo fue una cuñada quien la motivo a comprar más productos. Sus propósitos son  de seguir adelante con su negocio ya que todo lo que tiene actualmente le ha costado mucho esfuerzo y no lo perdería. Es por eso que solicita ayuda a Fundación León 2000 con el fin de comprar más productos para su negocio como vestidos, pantalones, camisetas, uniformes, cremas colonias, pinturas entre otras cosas. Ella sueña con tener su propia tienda que genere fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Señora Karla Elisa is 32 years old, and has 1 child in school who is 5 years old. Karla devotes her time to selling general merchandise. This started out of necessity in order to earn an income for her family, and her sister-in-law helped her get started and convinced her to buy more products. Her plan is to move forward with the business, since she has put a lot of effort into it and she does not want to lose it. For this reason, Karla is requesting help from Fundación León 2000 with the goal of purchasing more inventory for her business, like dresses, pants, shirts, uniforms, body creams, makeup and other things. Karla dreams of having her own store that will generate a source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anagonou

texts.fr: A. Anagonou est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Anagonou vit à Cadjèhoun, à Cotonou depuis sa naissance. Mariée à ALLIMENTIN Norbert un maçon, Anagonou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Anagonou  a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses deux enfants. Le couple vit ensemble à Cadjèhoun, avec leurs enfants. Anagonou vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Pour y parvenir, Anagonou vend depuis une douzaine d’année, des racines de plantes (médicaments traditionnels) et également des cuire dents de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Anagonou s’approvisionne. Anagonou a obtenu déjà deux crédits à ALIDé et les a bien remboursés. C’est dans l’optique d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir son activité que Anagonou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Anagonou A. was born in 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Since her birth, she's been living in Cadjèhoun, in Cotonou. She's married to Norbert ALLIMENTIN, a mason, and she's the mother of two school-attending children. Anagonou has another child to support, in addition to her own. The couple lives together in Cadjèhoun with their children. Anagonou helps her husband with the family expenses. In order to do so, she's been selling, for about twelve years, plant roots (traditional medicine) as well as "cuire dents" (wooden chewing sticks) as an ambulant saleswoman. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international market in Benin. She already benefited from two loans from Kiva's partner, Alidé, and repaid them without problems. In order to bolster her working capital and expand her business, she's seeking her third loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plant roots (traditional medicine) and "cuire dents" (wooden chewing sticks)

loans.name: Shehu

texts.en: Shehu is 25 years old and married without children. He hopes to get married very soon. He sells clothes to make a living, and hopes to own a boutique in the future. He sells for long hours to enable him to meet the needs and necessities of his aged parents. He hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more clothes to sell. This is the high season for sales and he hopes to meet the demands of his customers. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Kara Group

texts.en:
Here are Aminata K. and Fatmata K.. These are small scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000.00 to enable them to add more goods to their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profits. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing, and in their academic pursuits. 

Aminata K. (left) is the leader of this group. Aminata is approximately forty-five years of age. She was born in Mashinra, an outskirt of Makeni. Aminata is married with three children. Her husband is an electrician and her children are attending school – two are in junior secondary school and one is in senior secondary school. Aminata sells gara lappers (locally dyed clothes, sometimes with fabricated designs) and sometimes she also sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil). Aminata has been selling gara lappers for nearly twenty years now. She will use this loan to buy ten pieces of “brillians” (thirty yards of white cotton makes one brillian). She will also use part of the loan to buy different colors of ink, soda, powder and pay experts who make the designs on the cottons (brillian).

loans.use: To buy white cotton, inks, soda, and powder, and pay designers.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: A. Jeanne est née en 1959 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à MEHINTO Thomas, Jeanne est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Jeanne a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. C’est depuis quatre ans que Jeanne vit au quartier Cadjèhoun, à Cotonou, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Jeanne n’a fait que le cours primaire. Depuis près de 11 ans, Jeanne vend des tissus de façon ambulante, et aussi par le système de distribution. Jeanne s’approvisionne à Cotonou. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’accroître son activité pendant la période des fêtes de fin d’année, afin de satisfaire les demandes de la clientèle, Jeanne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Jeanne A. was born in 1959 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Thomas MEHINTO. Jeanne is the mother of three children, all in school. Jeanne supports another child besides her three children. For the last four years, she has been living, with her children and her husband, in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun, in Cotonou. The couple together provides for the family’s expenses.

Jeanne only went to elementary school. For almost 11 years, she has been selling fabric from door-to-door, and also through the distribution system. Jeanne stocks up in Cotonou.

She is a previous customer of ALIDé who fully reimburses her loans. In order to increase her working capital and to increase her activity during the end of the year festivities, Jeanne is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to meet her customers’ demand.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cloth.

loans.name: Alba Marina

texts.es: Alba Marina es una mujer que tiene 4 hijos, ella se dedica a una librería, hace más de 31 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que le ayudo muchos cuando sus hijos tenían que recurrir a clases, pero hasta los momentos ha logrado mantenerlo ya que este es su medio de vida y lo que le ha ayudado a soportar esta difícil situación. Además no es la primera vez que solicita crédito en Fundación pues ya lo había hecho y pagaba sus cuotas en tiempo y forma. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para cuadernos, marcadores, papel bond, lapiceros, borradores entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Alba Marina is a woman with 4 children who has dedicated her time to running a book shop for more than 31 years. She had a lot of help when her children were in school, but until now she maintains the shop since it is how she makes her living, and has helped support her through a difficult situation. This is not the first time she has asked for a loan from Fundación, as she has had loans before and always made her payments on time. She is asking for financing for working capital to purchase notebooks, markers, bond paper, pens, erasers and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Francis Ivania

texts.es: La señora Francis L. García tiene 29 años de edad, es casada con dos hijos menores de edad. La señora Francis tiene un negocio de venta de zapatos variados, joyas, cosméticos como mercadería en general además que también vende ropa, tanto nueva como usada.  Ella dio inicio a este negocio hace  8 años, este negocio lo empezó debido a que ya tenía experiencia en este tipo de actividades ya que anteriormente le ayudaba a su mama en la distribución de productos de cosméticos. Sus ventas las realiza principalmente por encargo, y también vende a crédito. El préstamo será invertido en la compra de inventario de ropa, joyas y zapatos, ya que se acerca una fecha buena para la venta de estos productos, y ella desea aprovecharla. El sueño que ella siempre ha tenido con respecto a su negocio es llegar a tener una tienda bastante grande en la que distribuya todos sus productos al por mayor.
texts.en:
Mrs. Francis L. García is 29 years old, and married with two dependent children. She has a business selling various shoes, jewelry, and cosmetics, as well as general merchandise including clothing, both new and used. She started this business 8 years ago, because she already had experience in this field since she helped her mom distribute cosmetic products. She makes her sales by orders, and she sells on credit.

This loan will be invested in buying inventory of clothing, jewelry and shoes, since a good season for selling these products is approaching, and she wants to take advantage of it. The dream she always had with respect to her business is to have a rather large store in which she can distribute her products wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rita De Los Angeles

texts.es: La Joven Rita es casada, tiene una niña de 4 añitos de edad, labora para el MINED de Nueva Guinea como maestra de primaria, está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 3er crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (construcción de una cocina), cuando Rita va a trabajar la deja a su hija con su mamá ya que vive con ella, su esposo trabaja como relojero y ambos se ayudan con los gastos de la familia,   Rita es una joven profesional con alto espiritud de superación personal, muy responsable, es una docente que ama su trabajo ya que ayuda a muchos niños  a aprender a leer y escribir de la colonia San Juan a 4 km de la Nueva Guinea carretera a Managua,  su sueño  es  terminar de estudiar la Licenciatura en Ciencias de la Educación, tener estabilidad laboral, salud  y una vivienda con mejores condiciones para su familia.
texts.en:
Young Rita is married and has a 4-year-old girl. She works for the Nueva Guinea Department of Education as a grade school teacher. She is applying for refinancing her 3rd loan to invest it in home improvement (building a kitchen). Rita leaves her daughter with her mother when she goes to work since she lives with her. Her husband works as a watchmaker and both help with the family expenses. Rita is a young professional with a lot of spirit for personal improvement and is very responsible. She is a teacher who loves her job since she helps many children learn to read and write from the San Juan neighborhood, 4 kilometers from Nueva Guinea on the road to Managua. Her dream is to finish her degree of Bachelor in Science of Education, have work stability, health and a house with better living conditions for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a kitchen

loans.name: Marguerite

texts.fr: D. Marguerite est née en 1956 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Marguerite vit à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis près de 20 ans. Marguerite est mariée à SALIFOU Mama Saïbou, un agent du Trésor au Bénin. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Marguerite vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Seul le mari de Marguerite supporte les charges de la famille. Marguerite n’a fait que le cours primaire à l’école. Il y a de cela 16 ans que Marguerite mène comme activité, la vente d’œufs à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Marguerite fait ses emplettes. Marguerite est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. C’est pour accroître son activité et également la diversifier, par l'acquisition et la vente de charbon de bois, que Marguerite sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marguerite D. was born in 1956 in Allada in the Atlantic County of Bénin. For close to 20 years, Marguerite has lived in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Marguerite is married to Mama Saïbou SALIFOU, a treasury agent in Benin. The couple supports three children; two of them are their own. All the children attend school. Marguerite lives together with her children and her husband. Marguerite’s husband alone provides for the family’s expenses.

Marguerite only attended elementary school. For 16 years now, Marguerite’s activity has been the sale of eggs from her home. Marguerite makes her purchases at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.

Marguerite is a previous customer of ALIDé. She has already received two loans from ALIDé; those have been paid in full. She would like to increase and also diversify her activity in acquiring and selling wood coal. Thus, Marguerite is requesting a third loan from AlLIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of egg crates and wood coal.

loans.name: Don't Worry Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Don’t Worry Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean leones each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, both in size and quality. Consequently, they will make more sales and better profits. As their profit-to-sales margin increases, they will better support themselves and their children.

The leader of this group is Kadiatu S., who is pictured in the middle. Kadiatu was born in Makeni. She is 32. She is married and has six children. Kadiatu’s husband is a driver. Three of her children are in secondary school, two are in primary school and one is not of school-going age. 

Kadiatu sells gara lappers (locally dyed clothes, sometimes with fabricated designs). She also sometimes sells slippers/flip-flops. Kadiatu has been selling gara lappers for a year now. Before that, she sold skirts. Kadiatu will use her share of the loan to buy working materials like white cotton, different colored inks, powder and caustic soda. She will also use part of the loan to buy a few dozens of slippers.

loans.use: Buy cotton, inks, powder, caustic soda and slippers

loans.name: Arlen Danya

texts.es: La señora Arlen L. García, es casada con un niño de 1 año y medio de edad. La señora Arlen L. se dedica a la venta ambulante de ropa usada. Cabe señalarse que ella ya tuvo crédito con nosotros y lo pago bien, ahora está solicitando debido a que desea aprovechar las ventas del mes venidero, ya que la gente usualmente compra ropa y calzado.  Ella dio inicio a este negocio hace 6 años, este negocio lo empezó con el que ahora es su compañero de vida, con el que le ha brindado el apoyo  para vender y hacer crecer el negocio. Cabe señalarse, su compañero de vida es Lic. En Computación, el cual aporta a los gastos familiares a través de su trabajo. El crédito será invertido en la compra de una paca de ropa seleccionada, principalmente pantalones azulones. Su meta siempre ha sido establecer un gran negocio de pacas seleccionadas que pueda estar ubicado en el mercado y que pueda vender al por mayor y al detalle, para ganar más y brindar facilidades económicas a su hijo en el futuro.
texts.en:
Arlen L. García is married and has a 1½-year old child. Arlen L. dedicates herself to being a traveling saleswoman of used clothing. It is worth pointing out that she has previously had credit with us, that she repaid in a timely manner. She is now requesting another loan to take advantage of selling for the summer season, given that people usually buy clothes and shoes during this time. She started in this line of work 6 years ago, in partnership with the person who is now her husband. He has provided her with support in selling her product and in growing her business. Her husband is a computer specialist, who supports the family with his income. The loan would be invested into the purchase of select clothing, primarily blue jeans. Her goal has always been to establish a good business in the market, and to be able to sell both at wholesale and retail. This would allow her to increase her earnings, and provide future financial security for her child.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Ka-Lomp Group

texts.en:
