S. and her husband seek to improve their standard of living by generating more income. They are asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase cows to raise and more vegetable to expand her business.  Tuy hopes to make more profit when she retails here vegetables to her customers. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: Buy cows and vegetables.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
“Work hard to achieve success.” That's an inspiring quotation shared by Julieta L. of Barangay Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. After her high school education, she got married to Pablo L. and they are blessed with five children. They want all of their children to be successful in their chosen professions so that they will be employed someday.

The major source of their income is through farming. They till their parcel of land twice a year. They plant rice, corn and some vegetables. Julieta is also engaged in selling fruits and vegetables, using her bicycle to roam around the village, to earn additional income.

Due to the high cost of commodities and school expenditures, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP10,000.00 to increase her vending capital in order to improve her small business. She believes that with her patience and sacrifices, she will be able to improve her small business and support the schooling of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital for her vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San H., 30, and her husband, Bunthoeun Lao, 44, have been married since 1999 and have two children: one son and one daughter. One attends school and other one is still young.  They live in a small village off of National Road number Two, about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

San has been a Chinese translator for a garment factory for four years. Her husband has farmed for more than 20 years. He grows tomatoes and cucumbers.  San is applying for her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorcycle to commute to work.

loans.use: Purchase motorcycle to commute to work.

loans.name: Pharng

texts.en: Pharng S. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Takeo province.  She is a professional weaver who makes a $1 profit every day.  Her husband makes and sells ice-cream.  On average, he earns $10 in revenue a day.  This couple is helped by one of their children who works in a garment factory.  Pharng is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase silk so that she can weave silk clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: Buy silk for weaving.

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina T. is 61 years old and resides in the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. Due to hardships and difficulties in life, she only finished high school. She has six children, of whom four are already married and two are presently studying. Her children are helping her when she has emergency needs. She hopes that her two children finish their studies and become successful in the future.

Lucina manages her business of vending native delicacies in their village. She sells different kinds of cooked snacks and also manages her hog raising business as an additional source of income. Because of her patience and sacrifices, she can earn a monthly income of Php 45,000, which she needs to budget for their daily needs and the schooling of their children.

For the continuous improvement of their business, she would like to borrow a loan of Php 15,000 from Kiva lenders. This amount will assist her to purchase more goods to make her business grow and to support the daily allowances and tuition needs of their children.

loans.use: Additional capital for her vending business

loans.name: Mrs. Phann Chok Village Bank Group

texts.en: Thirteen people living in Kruos village in Takeo province made up this village bank loan.  Phann C. is a bank president who selected the members.  They will use their loans for different purposes.  She is a fruit seller.  Her husband is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice.  They have a child who is a tailor.  Since her business is going well, she wants to expand by purchasing more cloths for sewing to support her customers.

loans.use: Buy more cloths for sewing to increase sales.

loans.name: Apolonio

texts.en:
Apolonio, 46, is a farmer who dreams of a better life for his family. He is married to Flora and has five children. The eldest child he has is 17 years old. With rice farming, he is determined to provide for the needs of his family and for the education of his children. Aside from rice farming, he also raises ducks as another source of income.

He requested a 15,000 Philippine peso loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to have additional capital to be used for his business. This loan will be helpful to make his business grow.

loans.use: Farm inputs and feed for ducks

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo N., 44, resides in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia with her husband and 18 year old child. To make a living, she and her husband buy and sell cows, earning an income of about $8.90 per day.  Her husband helps his wife in the business every day.  They seek to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income.  N. is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase more cows to resell.  She hopes to make more profit when she retails them to customers. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: Buy cows to sell.

loans.name: Uyanga

texts.en:
Uyanga is 35 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her three older children, who are 16, 14, and 12, attend a local secondary school while the youngest, age 4, attends a local kindergarten.

Uyanga sells dairy and milk products at the local market. She began her business in 2005 and has since stabilized her business and a base of loyal customers. The winter months are important for dairy retailers as the price for milk increases during this period. Uyanga is requesting a loan of 300,000 tugrug (~210 USD) to purchase a supply of dairy products in preparation for the price increases which will give her a greater profit margin.



About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here or copy and paste this url into a new web browser: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase a supply of dairy products.

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en:
Dennis D. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. He is 42 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Dennis makes and sells food, snacks and beverages in the local community. Dennis has been in business for over nine years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dennis joined HSPFI to access financial services to improve his living situation and to engage in business. Dennis has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI.  He is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sale.  This loan will be his second from HSPFI.  He plans to use the additional profit from the business to improve and expand his business. 
-----------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients to make products to sale.

loans.name: Mrs. Moeun Kruoch Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 20 people who live in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo province.  Moeun K. is the bank president who was selected by the members.  She is a farmer who owns a small field to cultivate rice.  Moeun is also a pig breeder.  She is applying for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.use: Buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Sophai

texts.en:
Sophai N., 29, and her husband, Hun Hor, 33, live on an island in Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 2001 and have two young daughters. One is in school. 

Sophai has been a silk weaver for almost 12 years. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village who sells to customers in Phnom Penh.  Her husband is also a silk weaver.  He used to be a wooden house builder. 

Sophai is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials to continue her family's silk weaving business.

loans.use: Purchase silk for weaving.

loans.name: Rath Theany

texts.en:
Rath Theany U. sells fish and chickens and breeds pigs.  She and her husband live in Kampong Svay village in Kandal province.  Her business is going well and she wants to expand by purchasing more fish and chickens to resell to earn more income. 

Her husband, Prech Mao, is a cooker who is hired by villagers during weddings, ceremonies, birthday parties, and so on.  Rath is 24 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.  Her husband is pictures to her right in the photo.

loans.use: Buy more fishes and chickens to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Gan-Ochir

texts.en:
Gan-Ochir is 55 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His second daughter, 19, attends university while the youngest daughter, 16, attends a local secondary school. His wife is employed as a guard at a local shop and Gan-Ochir sells firewood out of a warehouse.

He began his business in 2000 and started out selling cow dung for fuel. In Mongolia, dung, firewood and coal are the main sources of fuel for those living in gers and houses. Since 2000, his earnings have been the family's main source of income. Gan-Ochir is looking forward to being able to purchase a car to more easily transport his product from the countryside to town. He is requesting a loan of 450,000 tugrug (~310 USD) to purchase a supply of firewood and coal to sell during the winter months.


About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.


To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase a supply of firewood and coal to resell.

loans.name: Bella

texts.en: Bella, 52, owns a pig farm in Surallah, South Cotabato, which she started in 2004. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to borrow a loan which has allowed her to finance her business with a low interest. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php to buy feed for her pigs. She has three children and hopes to give them a brighter future by sustaining her business.

loans.use: To purchase feed.

loans.name: Thon

texts.en: Thon T. lives in Sambou village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.  His field is infertile and he does not have enough money to buy farming supplies to support the rice field. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline to support his rice field.  His wife, Khouv South, is a snack seller.  Thon T. is 53 years old and the father of four children, two of whom are farmers and the others are employed in a garment factory. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: Buy rice seed, fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline to support the rice field.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Rin S., 45 and his wife, Sothy Uk, 38, were married in 1982 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters.  Three of them have full-time employment.  Three attend school and the youngest stays at home.  The family lives in a small village off of National Road number Two, about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.

Rin and his wife are construction workers. 

The couple hopes to support their children's education so they will get good jobs when they finish school.  Rin is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to school.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for his children to ride to school.

loans.name: Badam

texts.en:
Badam is a 60-year-old widow who lives by herself in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. She lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and operates a dairy and flour retail business in her town. She began her business in 2006 by selling her products door-to-door. Her business was successful enough to allow her to rent a stall at a local market where she now sells her products. This business is her only income and she plans to continue working for as long as she is physically able. Badam says, “I do not want to trouble my children to take care of me. I am still strong enough to take care of myself and run my business.” She is requesting a 250,000 tugrug (~170 USD) loan to purchase dairy and flour in order to expand her business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase dairy and flour

loans.name: Rosally

texts.en:
Rosally D. C., 23, is one of the youngest entrepreneurs in Pasay City.  She is married to Roberto, a 25 year old seafarer.  They don't have children, yet.

Rosally sells fresh dressed chickens, fruit (bananas) and coconuts and been in business for six years.  She has a stall in Baclaran – a commercial district between the cities of Parañaque and Pasay.  Rosally has a hired hand so she can attend to her growing number of customers.  Rosally earns a net income of P26,000 a month.  

Rosally has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for two years now.  She has just finished repaying a previous loan on P30,000 and was very punctual in all of her payments.  Now, she is applying for a new P32,000 loan to buy additional merchandise.

She hopes to embark into other viable businesses soon.  Rosally dreams of owning a house and lot. 
----------------------------------------------
About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Rodelia

texts.en:
Rodelia L. is 37 years old and married to Amador L. Jr.  They live in Morong, a fine-looking place in the province of Rizal. She runs a sari-sari store (sells different goods) with the support of her loving husband. 

They have two children, the eldest is seven, a grade one student and a five year old in nursery school. 

Rodelia plans to use the loan to buy and resell different kinds of goods to support her family.  Her husband does not earn enough to cover their family expense.  She hopes to see herself enjoying the profits of her business and to have a good life.  Now, she is proposing a loan of Php 25,000.  Her previous loan was Php 20,000.  She has maintained a 100% credit rating with ASHI.  She has payed loans in full and on time.

She enjoys the benefits of having loans from ASHI because she progressively achieves her goals in life.  For almost five years Rodelia has shown industrious, discipline and given full time to her family and business to fulfillment her dreams.  She wants to build a strong concrete house and provide the best education for their children.

loans.use: Purchase food and merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Zagdzesem

texts.en:
Zagdzesem is 44 years old and lives with his wife and five children in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of his children, ages 18 to 9, attend a local secondary school while Zagdzesem operates a café and welding business with the help of his wife. His wife is the café cook and manager while Zagdzesem is responsible for the welding business. They used to sell meals door-to-door, but as they grew successful, they were able to purchase a shipping container where they now make their meals and sell them. In order to supplement their income, Zagdzesem also builds homes in the summer months. The family also has approximately 50 heads of livestock which they care for and use. He says, “My wife and I work hard to grow our businesses in order to be able to afford our children’s education.” Zagdzesem is requesting a 250,000 tugrug (~170 USD) loan in order to purchase food for their growing café business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase food for their growing café

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 55-year old rice farmer. She started her business in 2008. With her rice farming, she has been able to provide for her two children. Her eldest child is only 10 years old and she wants her children to be educated. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to get financial help for her business. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 Php, which is just enough to buy fertilizer and pay for the labor necessary to manage her rice field.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pay for labor.

loans.name: Veng

texts.en:
Veng V., 49 and his wife Sarim Saum, 42, (pictured) were married in 1987.  They have four children: three daughters, two work in a garment factory and the other attends school.  Their son is a construction worker.  They live in suburb of Phnom Penh

Veng has been a construction worker for seven years.  His wife stays at home and does housework.  They do not have a restroom in their home.  Therefore, Veng is asking for his first loan of $600 to build a restroom.  He will also use a part of his loan to buy a motorcycle for his children to drive to work.

loans.use: Build a restroom and buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Zevgee

texts.en:
Zegvee is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two adult children in the Uvs province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Zegvee sells livestock and animal meat. He purchases his product from the countryside and sells them in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, where the meat fetches higher prices. He started this business in 2006 after three years of running a felt retail business. Zegvee is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) to purchase a large number of livestock for the upcoming winter months which he can sell at a higher profit margin in the city.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.


To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia


To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase a large number of livestock.

loans.name: Baenorah

texts.en:
This is Baenorah B., 37 years old.  She lives with her husband Sonny, also a vendor, in Dasmariñas, Cavite where they migrated from Mindanao a few years ago.  The couple belongs to the Islam faith.  

Baenorah runs her own mobile phone shop selling different models of mobile phones and accessories.  She started her store selling a few mobile phone units and phone accessories two years ago.  Over the months, her store steadily grew and now offers repairs for damaged mobile phones and other services.  Then last month, she ventured into another business – ready-to-wear (RTW) clothing.  She now earns more than P28,000 a month.
 
She is now on her fifth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and has applied for a new loan in the amount of P14,000.  She will buy more items (phone accessories) to sell at her store.  She will also use a portion of the funds as additional capital for her new clothing business.   

She wants to see her mobile phones store to be bigger in the future than what it is now so she could help employ some of her neighbors.  She also looks forward to having their child soon. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell & additional capital for clothing business

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthorn P., 26 and her husband, Mr. Sinoeun Cheng, 25, live on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2005 and have just one young daughter. In the past, the couple worked as silk weavers. However, because traders are paying less for the finished fabric, they stopped the business and run a new business as well. 

Chanthorn is a chef; she cooks for a restaurant in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sinoeun Cheng has full-time employment in Phnom Penh as well. Unfortunately, the couple doesn’t have their own transportation to travel to work. That's why Chanthorn is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Chuchie

texts.en:
Chuchie farms rice for a living. She is 35 years old and has three children; the eldest of which is only six years old. In addition to her rice field, she has a pig pen. The income she gets from her business is enough to meet her family's needs.

Through Community Economic Ventures, Inc. she is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php to buy fertilizers and farming supplies. With this loan, she will be able to finance her business with a low interest.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and farming supplies.

loans.name: Tserendorj

texts.en:
Tserendorj B. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His 9- and 11-year-old sons go to a local school and the youngest 1-year-old stays home. Tserendorj has a small retail business with his wife. Tserendorj was a salesman in a flour-selling shop and in 2007, he decided to launch his own retail business in flour and related products. He rents a large container at the local food market, from which he retails bags of flour for locals. He mostly purchases flour from wholesalers and sell it to locals in a small bag. With the business profit, he was able to purchase an old car for his family and his family business. His family is the only source of income for his family. He says that since launching his own business, his family income has improved tremendously and he would like to expand his business as much as he and his wife can. He requests a loan to purchase more inventory bags of flour for his business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase more bags

loans.name: Holmahmad

texts.ru: Хочаев Холмахмад проживает в Гиссарском районе. Возраст 42 года. Женат, имеет  5 детей. Холмахмад более 7 лет работает зав.хозом, помимо этого он занимается животноводством, он откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для покупки крупно и мелко рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Holmahmad H. lives in the Gissar region. He is 42 years old. He is married and has five children. Holmahmad has bee working as a manager for more than seven years and besides that he also does animal husbandry. He feeds and sells cattle. He is asking for a loan to buy large and small cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina B. hails from the attractive municipality of Antipolo, Rizal Province, Philippines. She is a 59-year-old woman and a mother of six children. Four of her children only finished high school; two of them finished a vocational course and an undergraduate college. She is married to her caring husband, Antonio B., a factory worker.

              Carolina joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), a micro-finance Institution and a KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2004. Since then, she has had access to capital for her business, buying and selling assorted clothes for all ages. The business went effortlessly and successfully. For almost five years of membership in ASHI, she maintained her excellent performance. Now on her eighth loan, she is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase additional clothes for sale. Carolina is optimistic that her business will grow because her business also is in demand in the town. 

           Carolina's dream in life is that someday her children may finish their schooling even though they already have their own families. She wants to have steadiness for her future by saving the profits of her business.

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothes for resale

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia T. is a 48 year old mother of two children, one of whom studies in high school.  Her husband Jeremias, 51, is a carpenter.  They live in the poor neighborhood of Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Sophia owns a general store located in their house, and is also involved in the popular direct selling of cosmetic products and apparel offered by prominent brands (Personal Collection, Fuller Life, etc.).  With all these combined businesses, she earns a net income of P5,000 a month.
 
She is now on her sixth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative which she joined in 2006.  She applied for a P12,000 loan with the cooperative to purchase more cosmetic products for her clients.  She will also use a portion of the money as additional capital for her store.  Sophia dreams that her general store will become a big grocery store someday. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for the general store and direct selling of cosmetics

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong N., 48, and her husband, Mr. Chhen Sao, 52, live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1982 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of their children are garment factory workers and another two attend school.

Kong has been selling clothes and shoes for three months. She buys them from Phnom Penh market for resale in Sdao Kanleng market approximately 10 kilometers from her house. Her husband has been selling porridge in front of his house for five years.

Kong is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to purchase additional clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Crispina

texts.en: Crispina spends her time working with her rice field and piggery. She requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have additional capital for her business. She needs 14,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer, feed, and farm supplies. She has one child and is married to Danilo. Together they work hard to have a good harvest and earn more income to supply the needs of their family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im P., 45, is married and lives with her five children and her husband in the Takeo province. She and her husband are silk weavers who are able to earn approximately US$5 of profit every day. Currently, Im P. is asking for a loan of US$500 which she needs to purchase more silk. (Im P. is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase silk.

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Vorn N., 40, is married and lives with her two young children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who is able to make US$10 in revenue a day. She usually buys rice from growers and resells it to the market wholesaler. Her husband is a cow dealer and makes an average US$3 of profit per day. Vorn N. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase rice from growers to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase rice

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Нурулло Бегматова проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 22 года. Холост. Нурулло по специальности "экономист". Он более  3 лет занимается бизнесом, торговлей. Торгует он в основном хоз. товарами. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Nurullo B. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 22 years old. He is single. Nurullo's profession is an economist. He has been doing business, retail, for more than three years. He mainly sells household goods. He is asking for a loan to increase inventory turnover.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory turnover

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nop

texts.en: Nop S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and five children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are tailors who are able to make about US$6 of profit every day. Four of her children are in school and one is a garment factory worker. Nop S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase cloth to make clothes. (Nop S. is pictured with her husband from home)

loans.use: To purchase cloth.

loans.name: Tark

texts.en: Tark P., 57, is a widowed farmer who lives with one of her daughters in the Takeo province. She typically makes US$2 each day and would like to increase her profits. Her daughter who pictured with her from home is a hotel staff member. She typically makes US$5 of profit a day. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Tark P. included. She is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase fertilizer for the farm, increasing her current profits and prospects for the future.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase turnover

loans.name: Parn

texts.en: Parn V., 36, is married and lives in the Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make about US$3 of profit every day. She has one child and currently she lives with her mother and her sister. Her mother stays at home raising pigs and chickens to earn a living. Parn V. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase clothes to resell at the garment factory. This is a new business that she hopes will provide an extra benefit to raise her standard of living. (Parn V. is pictured with her mother from home)

loans.use: To sell clothes.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Mrs. Lina P., 21 (shown in the photo with her husband) and her husband, Mr. Lun Son, 34, have been married since 2006 and just have a 3 year-old son. The couple is living along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Lina has been a garment factory worker for 5 years, while her husband has been an electrician for 10 years. Lina is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase materials for her husband to use in the operation of his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim K. is 24 years old and lives with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province. She makes and sells hammocks at the local market to earn a living of US$1.60 of profit every day, while her husband is a seller and makes US$10 in revenue each day. He rides around to sell mosquito nets, pillows and hammocks in various locations around the community.  Sim K. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 that her husband needs to purchase a stock of mosquito nets, pillows and hammocks. (Sim K. is pictured with her husband)

loans.use: Sell mosquito nets, pillows and hammocks.

loans.name: Mareta

texts.en:
Mareta E. runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 30 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Lagunde, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. Mareta has been in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Mareta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mareta is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita A. is from the village of Bonbon Catarman, Camiguin. She is 39 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Mercedita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies, such as "bibingka", a typical Filipino rice cake, in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Mercedita joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma F. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Thelma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Thelma joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Serafín

texts.es: Serafín S. de 51 años de edad, reside en Cuyultitan en el departamento de La Paz, vive únicamente junto a su esposa, ya que sus hijos residen en el extranjero. Serafín cuenta con veinte años de tener un taller de reparación de zapatos ubicado en la calle principal de Cuyultitan. Serafín solicita un préstamo ya que desea invertir en su negocio, comprando nueva maquinaría y así mismo comprar repuestos para algunas máquinas. Serafín es un señor lleno de muchas metas, el cual desea tener una buena vida gracias a su esfuerzo laboral, es por ello que desea mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Serafín S., 51, lives in Cuyultitán in the department of La Paz. He lives alone with his wife, as his children are living abroad. For the past 20 years, Serafín has had a shoe repair shop located on Cuyultitán's main street. Serafín is applying for a loan because he desires to invest in his business by buying new equipment and spare parts for some of the machines. Serafín is a man with many goals; he desires to have a good life thanks to his hard work. That is why he wants to improve his business.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy spare parts for machinery

loans.name: Marcos Genry

texts.es: Marcos Genry R. M. de 22 años de edad, reside en el pueblo de Ilobasco, junto a su esposa y su pequeño de hijo de 8 meses de edad. El cuenta con un taller de serigrafía, negocio en el cual le ha ido muy bien hasta ahora. Marcos solicita un préstamo, ya que desea comprar material nuevo para su taller, haciendo un viaje al país de Guatemala, lugar en el cual podrá comprar dicho material a mejor precio. A pesar que hasta ahora Marcos ha tenido muy buenos resultados con su negocio, el desea mejorarlo, ya que su hijo es la razón la cual lo impulsa a trabajar aún más.
texts.en:
Marcos Genry R. M. is 22 years old. He lives in the town of Ilobasco with his wife and their small eight month old child. He has a screen-printing shop. This business has been going very well for him. Marcos is asking for a loan because he wants to buy new material for his shop. He will travel to the country of Guatemala where he will buy this material at a better price. Even though Marcos has very good results with his business, he wishes to improve it. His child is the reason that causes him to work even more.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for screen-printing

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly S. is from the village of Liposong Ozamiz City. She is 38 years old. Shirly is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Shirly owns & operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Shirly has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Shirly joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Shirly is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Shirly from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to pay for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en:
A business-minded woman from San Roque, Cardona in a beautiful province of Rizal has been engaged in her business for more than two years. Her business is direct selling of Avon products. She is also involved in the Fish Cage business. She believes that if her proposed loan is granted, it will be a big help for the expansion of her business. That is why she is very determined and disciplined to use the money which is lent to her. 

She disciplined herself to use all the money borrowed from ASHI, a KIVA partner, for her business to gain more profit. This profit is what she uses for daily expenses. She got involved with ASHI because of the family's dreams to send her children to school and finish their studies with a degree. She is a good mother of her two children and still dreams of the best for her family. She belongs to a poor family who needs help to change their standard of living and provide a beautiful house for her family in the future. All of these goals in life are supported by her loving husband, Norman A., a 23-year-old factory worker. Through the love between the couple, they are blessed with one child, Angelica A., 4 years old. This is the story of 28-year-old Gerlie A., a focused mother who is hopeful for her dreams.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Mr. Sin S., 41, pictured with his wife, Mrs. Sophoin Soun, 37, lives in a small village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1991 and have three children: two sons and one daughter.

Sin has been a farmer for 10 years, growing rice on his farmland in the village. His wife has been a silk weaver for 12 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Sin is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorized hand tiller for use on his rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.name: Elita

texts.en:
This is Elita A., a 49-year-old entrepreneur from Silang, Cavite. She hails from a farming family and is married to Patricio, 64, a bank employee. Three of their children are now in college, while one is in high school.

Elita owns and manages a computer shop catering to Internet surfers, gamers and students. She has been in this business for eight years and has an employee to assist her. She also has a general store, and when time permits, she also provides massage therapy. Elita, who makes P30,000 a month, enjoys dealing with customers of all ages and from different walks of life. Customer traffic peaks on weekends, she says.

She is now on her ninth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. Currently in need of funds to buy additional computer units for the expansion of her computer center and to upgrade some of her PC units, Elita is requesting a loan of P21,000.00 with CCT. She hopes to expand her computer center so she can save her earnings to enable all of her children to complete their education.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase additional computer units

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
This is Leticia M., a 58-year-old transport operator from Pasay City. She is married to Orlando, a 61-year-old jeepney driver. Leticia is a multi-tasking entrepreneur. She is into rag making, which she started five years ago. Along with production of rags, she maintains a coin-operated video karaoke machine. With still a little time left, she manages the operation of their passenger jeepney, which her husband drives daily. It plies the routes covering the city. They bought the jeepney and acquired a permit for public conveyance three years ago. Leticia earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from her businesses. Most of the profits go to her grandchildren's education.

Leticia considers her membership with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative a heaven-sent blessing. She wants to share with friends the many blessings she has received since joining the CCT. She is currently in need of a loan amounting to 22,000 PHP in order to purchase much needed spare parts for the repair and improvement of their passenger jeepney. She believes that their jeepney is God's gift to them.

About CCT:
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

He then started a sales business. Alisher has his own store where he sells groceries. He has been in this business for more than three years. He is asking for a loan to increase turnover.

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en:
T. Uranchimeg is 40 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest son currently works as an assistant at a local grocery shop, her two daughters and youngest son all attend a local secondary school, and her husband is employed as a security guard at the local market.

Uranchimeg operates a shoe making business in her town with the help of a friend. She started her shoe repair business in 1993. After years of successful operation and gaining experience, she broadened her business activity and started to produce both European and Mongolian shoes. Today she is very experienced and skillful in her trade and her product quality is on par with many of the leading shoemakers in Mongolia. Uranchimeg's business is very important to her and has provided financial security for her family. She hopes to save enough money to expand her business in the near future and support her children's school tuition payments. She says, "I hope to have my own working place in the future and I want my children to inherit my business when they get older." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase rubber and other materials used in making Mongolian traditional shoes. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon
