loans.name: Badamgarav

texts.en: Badamgarav H. is 47 and lives with her husband and her two children in Tuv province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter is 24 and a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and her youngest son is 6 and goes to a local secondary school. Badamgarav rents a small stall in the Altan-Eh shopping center, one of the town's large shopping centers. She has been selling various food products at her rental stall since 2008. Her retail business has grown fast and her business capital has expanded from 1,000,000 MNT to 4,300,000 MNT ($1 = 1,450 MNT) in a year. She would like to expand her growing business and purchase necessary equipment. She says that she needs to purchase a fridge with a glass cover for selling ice cream and other frozen products. She requests a loan to purchase a fridge and increase her working capital for her business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team. To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma has a rice-farming business on land that she owns. She is 39 years old but eager to till the land to make it useful and productive. Emma supports six children in her family. Her eldest is 24 years old. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to have financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos to buy materials for maintenance of her rice field.

loans.use: Farm materials

loans.name: Federita

texts.en:
Federita G. is a 73-year-old farmer from Talibon, Bohol. She has been tilling the rice field to be able to ensure enough food for the family. Though she is 73, she is still strong and very efficient to manage a business. 

She would like to apply for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to pay the laborers who help prepare the soil. She will also use the loan to buy seeds and for irrigation as well.

loans.use: Payment for the laborers and farm-equipment rental

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Like most enterprising housewives in the Philippines, Adelaida C., 47 years old, makes a living from the buying and selling of cosmetic items, apparel, shoes and bags from prominent direct-selling companies like Avon, Boardwalk, Natasha, Marikina Shoe Exchange, etc. This is a tried and tested source of income. She also sells load credits for mobile phones and now earns net income of P10,000 a month from the combined proceeds of her businesses. Adelaida’s family lives in Pasay City, a bustling community in the middle of the metropolis. Her husband, Cecilio, 44, is a non-medical staff member at the Makati Medical Center in the adjacent city. They have two children, one of whom is in college while the other is in high school. A large portion of Adelaida’s profits go to her children’s educational expenses. Adelaida joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative and has applied for a new loan for the same amount. This will be her tenth loan. She will use the funds to purchase cosmetics to meet her commitments on her clients’ advance orders. Adelaida dreams of seeing all her children finish their college studies. She also wishes to own a new house and lot for her family. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To pay for advance orders of cosmetics for her clients

loans.name: Salud

texts.en: Salud Bacaltus is a fish vendor. She earns income from selling fish in her village. She has nine children. She dreams of having more capital to support her fish-selling business. She plans to buy more fish from other fishermen. She will sell the fish to other towns for income. She needs a loan of 21,000 Philippine pesos to realize her plan. The loan that she will receive will not only provide a livelihood to her family but education to her grandchildren as well.

loans.use: To buy additional fish to resell

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida V. lives on an island. She has a sari-sari store and sells a variety of goods. Her family relies on the income from her business. That is why she is doing the very best she can to make it flourish and be productive. She has one child and has been married nearly 30 years.

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 10,000. The loan will be helpful in raising the income for the entire family's needs. She will buy additional merchandise to attract more customers and increase her sales.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Tapaga

texts.en:
Tapaga L. is a 41-year-old woman living in the town of Taga. She is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Tapaga owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food products in the local community. Tapaga has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities. In 2008, Tapaga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tapaga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Tapaga is now requesting a new loan of 2000 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Tapaga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cecil

texts.en:
Cecil P. owns a sari-sari store. She is happy about her business because it helps her provide for the needs of her family. Her husband is a fisherman. Aside from fish, her family relies on the income she makes in her store. She has five children and her eldest is just 18 years old. She is doing the very best she can to improve her business. 

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 16,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Chhea

texts.en:
Mr. Chhea A., 47, and his wife, Mrs. Sun Leng, 45, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They  married in 1980 and have eight children: six sons and two daughters. Three of their children are married and live in their own homes; the others are in school. 


Chhea and his wife have been growing rice for 29 years. They have also started a new business raising pigs. Chhea is requesting his second loan of $1,000 to buy more piglets to raise and to buy feed for the pigs.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and buy feed for pigs.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia V., 29 years old, is living on the island of Nocnocan Bohol. She sells fish to nearby villages to earn an income for the family. Her husband is a fisherman. Both of them work to raise their four children well. 

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fishing nets for her husband and a barrel of fish to resell. Receiving a loan will help a lot in improving the family's economic condition and supporting all their needs.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and fish to resell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan C. is from the village of Salawagan, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old and married. To make a living, Susan sell vegetables and other cooking ingredients. Susan has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used as additional capital for the business. Susan is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the seventh loan that Susan has  taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and serves low-income households in Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar A., 38 years old, lives in a poor community in Parola, Tondo, Manila – a shanty town at the edge of Manila Bay.  Her husband Rodrigo is a driver.  One of their two children is now in grade school.
 
Maricar’s general store has been in operation for two years.  Her neighbors buy rice, grocery items and other basic household necessities from her store.  She also has a soft drinks dealership.  Maricar makes a net revenue of about P15,000 a month.  She uses her profits to sustain daily family needs and to support her child’s education.

She is among the newest members of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She has just finished repaying a previous loan to the cooperative.  She has applied for a new loan of P9,000 as additional capital to continue the growth of her business.  She will use this loan to restock non-perishable grocery items, rice and soft drinks at her store.

Maricar wishes to see her store to grow to the size of  a mini-mart or a supermarket someday.   



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To restock non-perishable grocery items

loans.name: Onolina

texts.en:
Onolina P. is a 32-year-old woman living in the town of Falealupo Uta . She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Onolina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Onolina has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Onolina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Onolina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Onolina is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Onolina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Firas

texts.en:
Firas is a young Palestinian man. He is 25 years old, and he lives in Ein Yabroud village next to Ramallah City. Firas is a member of a big family consisting of 8 members. He and the whole family (the adults) work at selling Carob Juice during summer in the streets of Ramallah city and coffee during the winter. In addition to that, they also distribute the juice and coffee at big events like weddings, meetings, parties, and funeral receptions.

Firas requested 2000 USD from FATEN to buy big thermoses, a refrigerator, and carob (this is the season for it). Firas appears in the attached picture.

loans.use: buy thermoses, carob, coffee

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly S., 34, lives in a Habitat for Humanity village at the heart of a former slum community in BASECO, Port Area, Manila.  Her husband, Reynaldo, also 34, works for a construction firm.  They have three children, two in grade school.
 
Beverly owns a sari-sari (general) store, which she opened two years ago.  Her profits fulfill the family’s basic daily needs.  She also is able to save some money for her children’s education.  She now earns more than P13,000 a month.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in late 2007, and has enjoyed the camaraderie of her fellowship group since then.  Beverly is now on her fifth loan cycle.  She has finished repaying a loan of P10,000 and she has applied for a new loan of P12,000 to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

Beverly dreams of seeing her children to finish their schooling.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell at her store

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena B. is from the town of Northern Poblacion, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Nena is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Nena owns & operates a business selling specialty foods like banana cue and fruit salad in the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,750 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey S., 49, and her husband, Mr. Ra Sok, 54, were married in 1978 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. One child is married and lives outside the family home, two have full-time employment, one daughter assists her mother in the business and the youngest daughter attends school. The family lives in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Srey has been selling vegetables in Phnom Penh for 10 years. She does not have her own motorbike to transport vegetables to sell, so she is asking for a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike  to carry vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife C. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old. Marife is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marife owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, vending fish in the local community. In 2008, Marife joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marife has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional capital for the business. Marife is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to reinvest in her business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Marife from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina R. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 35 years old. Marina is married and has 3 young children. To make a living, Marina owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Eteli

texts.en:
Eteli F. is a 49-year-old woman living in the town of Asau. She is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Eteli owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Eteli has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Eteli joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eteli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Eteli is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Eteli plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Koeun H., 53 and her husband, Mr. Son Sut, 69, got married in 1978 and have 8 children: 6 sons and 2 daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home; one is a garment factory worker and three others attend school. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Her husband is a farmer.

Koeun has been a silk weaver for 40 years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business

loans.name: Ernesto Jr.

texts.en:
Ernesto, 41, owns one and one-fourth hectares of land. His one hectare is planted with corn, which gives him 50 sacks during harvest, costing 15,000 PHP. The remaining 1/4 hectare is a rice field, which gives him a harvest of 15 sacks or the equivalent of 10,000 PHP. He works hard to meet his target income during harvest time.

He heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., which helps entrepreneurs like him. He joined and requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy five sacks of fertilizer and other farm needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm inputs

loans.name: Channy

texts.en:
Mrs. Channy L., 44, is a widow and lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has five children: 4 sons and 1 daughter. One of them is married and lives outside the family home; one has full-time employment and the other three attend school.

Channy has been a silk weaver for 4 years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business and pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen M., from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin, is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To earn a living, Helen makes and sells charcoal made of coco shells in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to acquire additional inventory and working capital, she is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, her third, to invest in expanding the business. Helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to continue to improve her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Felister

texts.en:
Felister is 40 years old and married with three school-age children. She runs a grocery business in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She sells onions, tomatoes, and potatoes and employs one other person. Felister has been in business for eight years and has successfully completed a previous loan for Kes. 40,000. She requested this loan from Faulu for Kes. 80,000 to expand her business by cereals to her inventory. 

She describes herself as hardworking and says that her dream for the future is to be self-dependent and supply her goods from her own shamba (farm).

loans.use: Add stock of cereals

loans.name: Anafe

texts.en: Anafe R. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 28 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Anafe owns and operates a clothing business selling ready-to-wear items. She also runs a side business selling snacks, fish and vegetables. She has been engaged in her businesses for over ten years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Anafe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Anafe is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in another business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the businesses to purchase additional inventory, to use as working capital, and to pay off her weekly obligations to HSPFI. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in another business

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar is a young, single, Palestinian man. He is 28 years old and lives with his family which consists of eight members. He works as a secretary in the Ministry of Higher Education in the Palestinian National Authority.

Omar requested 3,000 USD from FATEN to start up a new business selling computers and computer accessories in order to increase his income. He has some experience to start such a business, and he will share this business with another person who has more technical experience in this regards. 
He appears in the picture at his newly established business

loans.use: To start up a new business selling computers and computer accessories

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
This is Judith D.. She is 41 years old. She lives in a shanty village at the heart of Parola Compound, Tondo, Manila. She lives there with her husband John, a 46-year-old security guard, and their seven children. One child is in high school, and three children are in grade school.

Judith got into business six years ago. She now has a sari-sari (general) store located in front of her house. She also maintains a coin-operated video karaoke machine. At the same time, she also sells ready-to-wear clothing. She earns a total net income of 16,000 PHP a month from these business activities. She uses most of her profits to support the education of her children.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. Judith applied for a new loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP to use as additional capital for her businesses. She is due to purchase more grocery items for her general store.

Judith dreams of having a computer shop in her community. She also wishes to have a new house and lot for her family.

About CCT:
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell at her store

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda T. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 55 years old. Rosenda is married and has three adult-age children. To make a living, Rosenda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosenda has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosenda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 51 years old and married with two school-age children. She has a tailoring business in Kitengela, a small town near Nairobi. She has been in this business for six years and makes a variety of clothes. She describes herself as focused and hardworking and says that the training she has received from Faulu has changed her way of thinking about business.

She has requested this loan for Kes. 20,000 from Faulu to buy two more sewing machines. In the future, she hopes to be the best tailor and eventually own her own plot of land.

loans.use: Buy more sewing machines

loans.name: Asiya

texts.en:
Asiya is 30 years old, married with one child who is 4 years old . She also takes care of one dependent from another family. Asiya lives in Nyarugenge in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda, where she has had a small shop selling various styles of clothes for men and women for many years. This is her 8th year of successful operation in this business! The hours of her shop are from 8AM to 9PM every day except Saturday.

Asiya is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to expand her business through purchasing some other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes and colors. With this loan, Asiya hopes to attract more customers to her shop and hopefully earn more profit in the process. This, in turn, will allow her and her devoted husband to move closer to their dream of buying a house of their own - also, it will allow her to provide more and better food for her family and her dependent.

loans.use: Purchase more variety, styles and sizes of clothes for sale

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz D. C. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 40 years old. Paz is married and has four school-age children. To make a living, Paz owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle services to local community members. Paz has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Paz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Paz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2009 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Paz is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Paz from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia, 42, runs a rice farming business. Her rice field in Surallah, South Cotabato is 3 hectares wide and she is looking forward to expanding her business in the future. Eugenia joins Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of 15,000 Php to improve her rice field, as she would like to provide better financial support to her 11 year old child.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
B. is 27 years old, married with two children aged 2 and 7. She lives in the Gasabo District of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here she owns a shop selling a wide variety of goods. This is her second year in this business and so far things are going well for B..  She is a self-employed businesswoman and very proud of that fact.  B.'s shop is open from early in the morning until late in the evening each day except Sunday.
 
B. is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional merchandise such as sugar, sorghum flour, and a refrigerator to keep some of the drinks she sells cold to attract more customers. By using this loan, B. hopes to increase her monthly profit compared to what she earned before this loan request. In addition, she will save for her children so that when they are both attending school, she will be able afford to take care of them and feed them properly.

loans.use: Household items, sugar, sorghum flour, and a refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more equipment

loans.name: Virgelia

texts.en:
Virgelia D. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 51 years old. Virgelia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Virgelia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Virgelia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Virgelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgelia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Virgelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sroin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroin K., 44, and her husband, Mr. Nheb Eng, 48, married in 1982 and have two sons. One son is married and lives separately and the other attends school. The family lives in a small village across the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sroin K. and her husband are rice farmers. She is asking for a loan of US$ 800 to purchase a water pump and pipe to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and pipe to use on her rice farm

loans.name: Tauilo

texts.en:
Tauilo S. is a 40-year-old woman living in the town of Falealupo. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Tauilo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Tauilo has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Tauilo joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tauilo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Tauilo is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Tauilo plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn and her husband Ronald have four children, the eldest being ten years old. They operate a rice farm and duckery to support their family. Evelyn is a member Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and would like to request a loan of 12,000 Php to support her business. This loan will be very helpful to provide supplies necessary for the farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Bienvenido

texts.en:
Bienvenido T. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan De Oro City. He is 54 years old. Bienvenido is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Bienvenido owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Bienvenido has been engaged in his business for over 43 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Bienvenido joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bienvenido is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Bienvenido from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en:
Speciose is 44 years old and married. Speciose and her husband take care of 3 dependents aged 9,12, and 20. Speciose and her family live in the northern province of Rwanda, in a place called Nyarugenge, which is approximately 3 hours' drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here, Speciose has had her own butcher shop for the past four years. The demands of her business require that she work from 6 AM to 7 PM every day except Sunday.

This is Speciose's second loan; she paid back her first loan in full and on time. Her business has been a bit slow recently and her working capital is strained. Speciose believes that if she gets her second loan, she will be able to supply sufficient meat and meat products to her customers and purchase needed supplies. Any profits that Speciose earns from the products that she purchases with this loan she will reinvest in her business to strengthen her balance sheet.

loans.use: Purchase more meat and supplies for sale

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
This is Rosario P., 65 years old.  She and her husband Venerando, 67, are vendors.  They live in Parola, Tondo, Manila- a shanty community very near Manila Bay.  They have two children.
 
Rosario has been doing business for twenty-five years.  She buys and sells assorted fruit.  Her fruit dealership now earns more than P50,000 a month.  She grew tired of moving around delivering fruit so she is looking forward to having her own fruit stall near their house or in the market.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 1998.  Rosario has applied for a new loan in the amount of P50,000.   With this additional capital, she plans to purchase more assorted fruit for her business.

Rosario hopes to send all her grandchildren to school from the fruit of her labor.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert B. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. He is 45 years old and married, with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gilbert owns and operates a boarding house, and provides these services to local community members. Gilbert has been engaged in his business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gilbert joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Gilbert is requesting his first loan from HSPFI.  This loan, for 5000 PHP, will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service.  Gilbert plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and serves low-income households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 38-year-old widow with two children, ages 16 and 20. She has a boutique in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She sells a mix of mutumba (used clothing) and new materials. She's been in business for ten years. She describes herself as hardworking, innovative, and faithful.

She requested this loan for 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu to add more stock to her shop. Her hope is to expand her business in the future and become economically stable.

loans.use: Add clothing stock

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mr. Sophea S., 26, and his wife, Mrs. Kea Chanmakara, 28, live on an Island of Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2004 and have a young son.   

Sophea and his wife are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. He is requesting his first loan of $200 to purchase materials for his and his wife’s silk weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for the family silk-weaving business.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: This 44-year-old farmer, Gina, is already a widow but strives hard to make a living. She grows rice in Surallah, South Cotabato. She needs additional capital to purchase farm supplies and fertilizer, and to pay for land preparation. She has joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will help her to meet her needs for the farm and for the support of her 3 children in school.

loans.use: Farm supplies, fertilizer, labor

loans.name: Lorina

texts.en:
Lorina E. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 65 years old. Lorina is married and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lorina raises pigs for sale. Lorina has been engaged in her business for more than 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Lorina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Lorina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lorina is seeking a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lorina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family income. 

About HSPFI:

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

Miriam B. is from the village of  Sagay, Camiguin. She is 41 years old and married, with one school-aged child. To make a living, Miriam owns and operates a sari-sari (general) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Miriam has been engaged in her business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb P., 40, and her husband, Mr. Khim Nhoem, 47, live in a small village across the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1986 and have two daughters; one of them attends school and other one is still young. And one son is assisting his mother in the business.

Chroeb has been raising pigs and cows for five years. Her husband is a policeman. She now is requesting a loan of US$ 300 to purchase additional cows to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows to raise

loans.name: Jossie

texts.en:
Jossie P. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 42 years old. Jossie is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Jossie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. At the same time, Jossie buys and sells gold dust. Jossie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jossie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jossie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Jossie is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jossie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is 58 years old and married with 4 children. He repairs printing machines and sells printing materials. He hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more printing materials to sell. He hopes to expand this business. His greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more printing materials

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 40 years old and is married with 3 children aged 12, 19, and 21. She lives in the Nyarugenge District of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Joyce has been a proven entrepreneur for over 9 years in the business of selling new and used spare parts. Joyce is good at what she does and works very hard; she employs two people as helpers in her business.

Joyce is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase some additional new and used spare parts for her shop. With this loan, Joyce will be able to serve more customers as well as earn more profit, she believes. With any additional profits earned, Joyce will reinvest in her business and put aside some as savings since she hopes to be economically independent in the years ahead. In addition, she will also continue to take care of her family's daily needs.

loans.use: Purchase more used and new spare parts for sale

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane A. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin. She is 32 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts and at the same time she owns a sari-sari store in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Jane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Mary Jane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica L. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 31 years old. Veronica is married and has 3 infant children. Veronica has a sari-sari (general) store from which she sells food & daily use products to the local community. Veronica has been in business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (about $106 US) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Veronica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business.  This loan will be the 5th loan Veronica has taken out from HSPFI. Veronica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to  expand the business. Veronica is requesting another loan of 11,000 pesos which will also be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 25 years old and is single. She takes care of her brother and a 3-year-old orphan of a deceased relative. She lives in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Jeanne is a hardworking businesswoman, owning and operating a popular local restaurant in which she employs ten people. This is her 4th successful year in business. The hours of her business require that she works from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Jeanne struggles to make a profit each month and believes that she does not carry enough variety of drinks and food. Also, she needs supplies. To this end, a small amount of additional capital would help her business to grow in a meaningful way.

For that reason, Jeanne is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase these additional items and supplies so that she may serve her existing customers better and attract new customers. This she expects will mean an increase in her sales.

If her strategy is successful, Jeanne will be able to build a stronger business and put aside some savings for a more secure future for herself and her young family.

loans.use: To purchase food, beverages and supplies

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: To earn a living, Fatima sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers in the market. She hopes to sell her foodstuffs at wholesale prices in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 35 years old and married with 4 children. Her husband is a government worker. Her eldest child is 20 years old. She is a focused, hard worker. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Esther Wambui

texts.en:
Esther Wambui is an industrious lady aged 40 and a mother of two aged 15 and 13. She is married to Anthony, a businessman aged 46. She has been selling clothes in the heart of Kakamega town for the last five years. She started this business with some funds she had obtained from her husband.

This will be her first loan from KADET. She intends to use the money to increase her stock of clothes to prepare for the holiday season, when demand for clothes is highest. She hopes to make a great profit, since the loan she has accessed from KADET will enable her to stock her business well. She has been supporting some neighbors who are orphans and she projects that since she expects to have increased sales, the aid she offers to these families will also go up.

Esther aspires to expand this business into a wholesale boutique shop. She also has a goal of empowering her children with education in the best way possible. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Hydie

texts.en: Hydie, age 27, manages a rice farming business in Surallah, South Cotabato.  She is the mother of two children, the eldest is 8 years old.  With rice farming, she and her husband Bryant are able to support their family.  Hydie is requesting a 13,000 PHP loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help support the needs of her farm. She will use it to buy farm inputs.  She is grateful to CEVI for the opportunity to receivel a loan with a low interest.

loans.use: To help support the needs of her farm.

loans.name: Whycliffe Nabuteya

texts.en:
Whycliffe A. is 53 years old and married to Jane, age 41. They have one daughter, age 22, who just completed high school. Whycliffe runs a pharmacy in Kakamega Town, about 600 kilometers of Nairobi, the capital city. He has been in this business for the last 16 years.

This is Whycliffe's first loan from KADET Ltd. and he will use the money to purchase more drugs for his pharmacy. He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a friend who is already an existing client.  He aspires to build rental houses to earn additional income and wishes to provide his daughter with as much education as she desires.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock of medicinal drugs.

loans.name: Ikechukwu

texts.en: Ikechukwu is 27 years old and single without children. He sells phone accessories at retail prices to his customers. He sells for long hours so he can support himself and his aging parents. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more phone accessories to  sell. This is the high season for business and he hopes to meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to own a phone company in the future. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Eleni

texts.en:
Eleni E. is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of Auala. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Eleni owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Eleni has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Eleni joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleni has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Eleni is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Eleni plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.
