loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.ru: Махбуба Давлатова проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 41 год. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж работает в месной школе учителем. Сама Махбуба более 7 лет занимается бизнесом. Она имеет троговую точку на рынке, где торгует одеждой. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Mahbuba D. lives in the city of Kulob. She's forty-one years old, married and has four children. Her husband works as a teacher in a local school. Mahbuba has been in business for more than seven years, selling clothes on the market, where she has her own shop. She is asking for a loan to increase her goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy new supplies

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 43 years old, married with 3 children and lives in Hebron, Palestine. He is a small entrepreneur who sells various kinds of foodstuffs such as cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, macaroni, detergents and many other items in his grocery store. Mohammed decided to take a loan to buy additional canned goods and other supplies for his store.

Your support will really help him. Mohammed is counting on your help.

loans.use: Buy additional goods for his store

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en: Solomon is 47 years old and married with 4 children. His eldest child is 19 years old. He sells groceries and frozen foods at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a supermarket in the future. He hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and frozen foods to sell. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs and necessities of his immediate family members. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and frozen foods to sell

loans.name: In

texts.en: In B. is 48 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 per day, while her husband works collecting palm juice to refine into palm sugar. On average, he is able to make about US$3.30 daily . This couple has six children, two of whom are students and four are employed as garment factories workers and construction workers. In B. is asking for a loan of US$1200. Her husband wants to purchase a motorbike so that he can operate a moto-taxi to provide them with additional income. (In B. is pictured here with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase a moto-taxi.

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Lita U. is a 26-year-old woman living in the town of Salelologa. She is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Lita owns & operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing dress-making services to local community members. Lita has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lita joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 400 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional equipment & implements such as needles & thread. Lita is now requesting a new loan of 2000 WST which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Lita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Loleta

texts.en:
Loleta A. is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Pitonuu. She is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Loleta owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Loleta has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 350 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Loleta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loleta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Loleta is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Loleta plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Adyasuren

texts.en:
Adyasuren is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in a house in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. His oldest daughter, 12, attends a local secondary school and his younger daughter, 3, is in kindergarten. Adyasuren operates a welding business in his town where he repairs and builds metal products for his customers. He began his business in 2006 after working as a welder in a factory for several years. With his business profits, he was able to not only pay the tuition fees for his daughters’ education, but he was also able to build a house where his family could live comfortably. Adyasuren is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to expand his working space and overall business so that he can serve his customers better.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To expand his working space and overall business

loans.name: Chork

texts.en: Chork Y. is 27 years old and lives with her husband and two of her young children in the Takeo province. Since 2003, she has been working as a garment factory worker to earn a living and is able to make about US$2 of profit every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver who is able to make US$3 of profit each day. Chork Y. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike so that her husband can have his own moto-taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a moto-taxi.

loans.name: Oladipupo

texts.en: Oladipupo is 48 years old and married with 4 children. His eldest child is 19 years old. He has a bakery where he bakes bread to sell at wholesale and retail to his customers. He is a hard-working man and he hopes to lift his business and family above poverty. He hopes for loan amount of 100,000 to purchase more bags of flour to bake more bread to sell. He is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of flour to bake more bread to sell

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.ru: Баходур Сафаралиев проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 29 лет. Женат, имеет 1 ребенка. Баходур имеет высшее образованние. Он имеет хлебопекарню, где печет национальные лепешки, которые потом продает на рынке. Кредит просит для закупа сырья, т.е. муки.
texts.en:
Bahodur S. lives in Kulob City. He's twenty-nine years old, married and has one child. Bahodur has a college education. He owns a bakery, where he bakes ethnic flat breads, which he then sells on the market. He is requesting a loan in order to buy additional ingredients, such as flour.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase production

loans.name: Biyinzika Development Group A Of Mukono

texts.en: Robinah N. is 20 years old and cares for her one child in addition to her parents. She sells secondhand clothes at the local market and generates 30,000 USH per week from the business.  She would like to use the loan amount of 200,000 USH to purchase more clothing. Robinah believes that with greater inventory she will be able to boost business and attract more customers to her stall. She is very hard-working and hopes to be able to pay for the education of her child.

loans.use: Purchase more used clothing

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
Uuganbayar is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter, 20, attends university and her two sons, 14 and 12, both attend a local secondary school. Uuganbayar operates a home goods retail business in two shipping containers at her local market. She began her business in 2000 in a rented stall at the market and over the years, her business has grown and become successful. In the near future, she would like to purchase one more shipping container so that she can expand her business even further and grow her customer base. Uuganbayar is requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (~1620 USD) loan in order to purchase more home goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes, etc. for her growing business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase more home goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 40 years old and married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 17 years old. She sells plastics of various colors and sizes. She hopes for a loan amount of 150,000 NGN to purchase more plastics to sell. Her greatest joy in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to be a major plastic distributor in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics to sell

loans.name: Class Six Development Group Of Mukono

texts.en: Simon Lugolole is 38 years old and the leader of his group in Mukono. He is married with four children who are all enrolled in primary school.  For ten years Azam has sold charcoal and would like to use his loan of 300,000 USH to purchase more wood for burning. He hopes to remain able to continue providing for his family.

loans.use: Buy more wood

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario G., 60 years old, is a widow who lives with her four children in Tartaria, Silang, Cavite.

She buys and sells ready-made curtains for walls, windows, and doors. She also sells hand-painted wall calendars.  Rosario earns P5, 000.00 a month, more or less.  Her income varies day-to-day because she has no regular clients.  Her profits provide for her family’s daily basic needs.   

Joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative has made Rosario a lot of new friends.  She is in need of a fresh loan in the amount of P13, 000.00 as additional capital for her curtain business.  This would be her tenth loan cycle.  


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: For additional capital for her curtain/hand-painted calendars business

loans.name: Kevin Makhanu

texts.en:
Kevin Makhanu is a married man aged 35 and a father of two, aged seven and three. He operates a pharmacy in Kakamega town, and this he has been doing for the last nine years. He runs this business with assistance from his wife Bridgid, who is a trained and registered nurse.

Kevin just joined KADET Limited so this will be his first loan. He was introduced to KADET by his neighbor, who is an existing client. He hopes to use this money to purchase more medicine stock for his pharmacy.

He aspires to expand his business and open a wholesale outlet.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock of medicinal drugs

loans.name: Babyelesa Women's Group Of Mukono

texts.en: Clement B. is 50 years old and the leader of her group in Mukono. She is married with nine children whose ages range from 30 years old to 20 years old.  Many of her children have graduated from University.  She is involved in the dairy business and generates 150,000 USH per week from the enterprise.  Right now, the supplies of milk are low due to the season, so naturally the prices have gone higher for the product. Clement would like to use the loan to purchase the milk at these higher prices. With hard work and determination she one day hopes to be able to afford to build her family a house.

loans.use: Additional milk

loans.name: Siialuga

texts.en:
Siialuga V. is a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Sataua Uta. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Siialuga owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Siialuga has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 700 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Siialuga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Siialuga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1500 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Siialuga is now requesting a new loan of 2000 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Siialuga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ziyad

texts.en:
Ziyad is a young Palestinian man aged 27 years. He is married with three young children aged 4, 3 and 1 years old.

Ziyad owns a shop in Khanyounis, south of Gaza City at Gaza strip. In this shop he sells spare parts and accessories for motorcycles. In addition to that, he also fixes them and fixes bicycles, too. He gained his experience working for another shop before having his own.

Demand for bicycles and motorcycles in Gaza strip is very high because gas for cars is not available all the time and is also expensive since Gaza is now under tough siege. Ziyad has requested a loan from FATEN of 1,150 USD to pay for spare parts. He appears in the photo at his shop.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his shop

loans.name: Kyosimba Onyana Development Group Of Mukono

texts.en: Juliet N. is 42 years old and is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is no longer married and cares for her two children who have both been able to attain university degrees. She has been involved in the stationary business for three years and right now finds herself with little capital to fund purchases of additional stock. She is confident that with the 300,000 USH loan she will be able to boost her business and expand its inventory. She is hard-working and determined to succeed.

loans.use: More Inventory

loans.name: Immaculada

texts.en:
Immaculada, 49, has business in rice farming and hog raising. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to fulfill her needs in supporting the business since she has limited capital. She requested a loan of 11,000 Php to buy farm supplies and piglets.

The income she will receive is very helpful in sustenance of her family. She has 6 children to support and would like them to have a better future.

loans.use: Farm supplies and piglets

loans.name: Tary

texts.en: Tary is 38 years old, married with 2 children. His wife sells foodstuffs to make a living. He is a commercial motorcyclist. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his passengers. He has one motorcycle but he hopes to get another one to enable him convey more passengers to their location. He hopes to also hire a young boy to assist him.  He has been in this business for 2 years. He works for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He is requesting for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase a motorcycle. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.en:
A. Rafoat is 40 years old. She is a widow with three children. Rafoat owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items such as eggs, sugar, macaroni, vegetable oil, juices, soft drinks, etc. She deems it an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more foodstuffs to increase her stock of goods available for sale. Rafoat has run this business for 11 years. This business is the main source of her family’s income and she hopes that with the help of you she can improve her living by expanding her business. Thank you!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Foodstuff for selling for increasing of the stock

loans.name: Allah Yaguba Group Of Mukono

texts.en: Sarah N. is 23 years old and the leader of her group in Mukono. She is married and has one child, who is still a baby. Sarah sells secondhand shoes and has been doing so for two years. From this business, she is able to generate 50,000 USH per week. She would like to use her loan of 300,000 USH to purchase more shoes and boost business.  Her dream is to one day be able to afford a house for her family.

loans.use: More Secondhand Shoes

loans.name: Dulam

texts.en:
E. is a 37-year-old widow who lives with her three children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her three children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All three of her children attend university and E. operates a meat retail business out of a rented stall in a local market. She began her business in 1998 and in her eleven years in operation, she has gained many loyal customers and much experience. She is planning on building and opening a small grocery store next year so that she can increase her income and pay for her children’s tuition fees more easily. E. is requesting a 3,770,000 tugrug (~2650 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of meat for her business during the upcoming winter months.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of meat for her business during the upcoming winter months

loans.name: Zainura

texts.en:
A. Zainura is 27 years old. She lives with her husband, and their two children. Zainura works with her husband every day in the grocery store they opened together 7 years ago. Because demand for their grocery products has increased, Zainura is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni, which will be used to purchase key grocery items in bulk for resale. Zainura and her husband hope to use their business' earnings to provide a solid education for their children.  
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. loans.use: Foodstuff for selling for increasing of the stock

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en:
D. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and seven-year-old daughter in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and his daughter attends a local secondary school. With the help of his wife, D. operates a wooden product business in his town. He began his business in 2000 after borrowing his friend’s woodworking tools. In 2005, he received a loan from XacBank, one of the largest banks in Mongolia, in order to purchase his own woodworking tools. Because he has been in business for almost a decade, D. has increased his business experience and his customer base. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to purchase wood and other necessary materials for his woodworking business.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase wood and other necessary materials for his woodworking business

loans.name: Bayaraa

texts.en:
E. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three daughters in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest daughter, 19, attends university and his two younger daughters, 16 and 14, both attend a local secondary school. E. operates both a clothing retail business and a taxi service in his town with the help of his wife. His wife is responsible for the clothing business and E. is responsible for the taxi service. They began their clothing business in 1998 and because of years of successful operation, they were able to purchase a car and begin their taxi service in 2008. He wants to purchase a shipping container in which to expand his clothing business in the future. He says, “All I want is to grow my businesses and maintain them successfully.” E. is requesting a 3,200,000 tugrug  (~1620 USD) loan in order to purchase clothing and machine repair parts for both of his businesses.

About XacBank

It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase clothing and machine repair parts for both of his businesses

loans.name: Funmi

texts.en: Funmi is 30 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is an engineer. She sells sarongs and laces in the market. The demand for her sarongs is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She has been in this business for 4 years. She is a focused, hard worker. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Gulbuta

texts.en: Gulbuta has sold fabrics for women's national dresses at the market for many years. Her fabrics are some of the best at the market. By now she has many clients. She knows her business very well. She is married and the mother of 5 children. Her husband works as a cook. Gulbuta wants to borrow money to purchase more goods for selling and thus have more profit. With that profit, she can provide better living conditions for her family. loans.use: Purchasing more fabrics and expanding her business

loans.name: Bakuseka Magya Development Group Of Mukono

texts.en:
Prossy N. is 46 years old and the leader of her group in Mukono. She is divorced with 8 children whose ages range from 25 years to 6 years. Prossy has been selling dry fish for 17 years and generates 80,000 USH per week from the enterprise.

The fisheries are raising prices, though, and Prossy’s capital levels are too low to maintain her standard levels of inventory. She would like to use the loan of 300,000 USH to increase her stock and keep up with demand.

The good quality of the fish she sells has created a loyal customer base and she hopes to continue being successful. Her dream is to one day have a big stall in the market and to be able to educate her children.

loans.use: For increase of stock

loans.name: Byatshan

texts.en:
C. is a 39 year old widow who lives with her three children in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son attends university and her two younger children both attend a local secondary school. With the help of her mother, C. operates a dairy retail business out of a rented stall at a local market. She began her business in 2001 and has seen steady growth in her income since then. She says, “I would like to educate my children and expand my business in the future.” C. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of dairy products for her growing business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001 and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of dairy products for her growing business

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three children in an apartment in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends university and her two younger children both attend a local secondary school. Batbayar operates a clothing retail business out of a shipping container at a local market, where she sells both outer and under clothing. She began her business in 2000 in a rented stall at the local market. As her business grew, she was able to purchase a shipping container so that she could expand her product line. Currently, she travels to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, twice a month and purchases her products there. Batbayar says, “I am saving money for my children’s education. I want all of my children to be able to attend university.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to purchase a wide variety of clothes for her business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a wide variety of clothes

loans.name: Gompil

texts.en:
Gompil E. is 22 years old and lives with her parents in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. With the help of her parents, she operates a vegetable retail business in her town. Her parents grow vegetables, and she sells them in her stall. The family’s vegetable field is small, however, and she has to purchase vegetables in Ulaanbaatar so that she has something to sell to her customers. She began her business in 2004, and she has earned enough to build a storage building for her business. She stores excess foods there so that she can sell them during scarce times. Her working capital has now reached 3,000,000 tugrugs (about $2100 USD) and she would like to purchase more hectares of land for her family’s farm in the future. E. is requesting a 1,800,000 tugrug (about $1260 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of vegetables from Ulaanbaatar.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of vegetables from Ulaanbaatar

loans.name: Utkirjon

texts.en:
J. Utkirjon is 27 years old. He is married and has four daughters. Utkirjon uses his car to provide taxi services. He has been in this business for the last six years, and he has gained a rich experience on driving. Utkirjon always trys to provide high quality services at prices that are attractive to his customers. Utkirjon is doing his best to make his business stable and profitable because he is the main bread-winner in his large family. He is ready to work from early morning until late at night in order to keep his customers and to obtain new ones. Today his car needs thorough repairing, so he is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni. He wants to purchase spare parts such as wheels, antifreeze, and other parts. Utkirjon thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. The well-being of this family is in your hands.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Tajikistan has produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have access to viable business opportunuties. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Buy spare parts for repairing his car

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar T. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. Both of his children attend a local secondary school. His wife is currently employed as a salesperson at a grocery shop. T. operates a dairy product trading business in his town. He is quite knowledgeable and skilled in dairy production because he grew up in the countryside. T. started his business in 2008, and has found success in his first year of operation. His earnings have enabled him to purchase a house for his family, which has contributed greatly to their quality of life. T. has many plans for his business and will work hard to achieve his goals. He says, "With my future profits I am planning to buy livestock in order to produce dairy products myself." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (about $700 USD) loan to purchase dairy products to sell.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale, and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans.
