loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Rashidatu

texts.en: Rashidatu, 55, is married and has six children. Her husband is a mechanic. Rashidatu sells groceries at the front of her house in Ibadan, Oyo state. She is happy because she does not have to pay for stall rent. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries

loans.name: Pita

texts.en:
Pita J. is currently in the business of selling food in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase drinks like sodas, water, packed juice, etc., to sell. Pita is 28 years old and single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

About BRAC: BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase drinks like sodas, water, packed juice, etc.

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en: Iyad is a 33 year old man, He is married and has 3 children. Iyad owns small store where he sells all kinds of perfumes. He is interested in expanding his business, which is his main financial source, by purchasing more perfumes for his store.  He is requesting a loan of 3000USD for that purpose. Iyad thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing more perfumes

loans.name: Dorjhand

texts.en:
Dorjhand S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Bayanzurkh district in Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Her son and daughter both attend a local secondary school. Dorjhand operates a construction materials business with the help of her husband in their district. She started selling construction materials in 2007 and has quickly found success with her new business. She has gained much experience as a businesswoman and has built a good reputation among both her customers and suppliers. The business is very important for her family and has provided them with financial security. She says, "With my business earnings I can support my children's education and I am happy for that."

S. is optimistic about the future and hopes to soon expand her business, her dream being to own her own workplace in the future. She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2500 USD) loan to purchase construction materials for her business and to remodel her house.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her business and to remodel her house

loans.name: Kesia

texts.en:
Kesia L. is a woman living in the town of Sataua Uta. She is married and has 3 young children. To make a living, Kesia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Kesia has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Kesia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Kesia is requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Kesia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Hanin

texts.en:
Hanin is a young woman who is married with one child. She lives in Saffa Village south of Ramallah City. Hanin’s husband used to work in Israel in a pastry shop but three months ago they decided to start their own business since working in Israel depends on getting a work permit so it is not permanent work.

Hanin and her husband work together in making pastries, croissants, desserts, etc., and sell their products upon request within the village and to shops and restaurants in Ramallah.

Hanin has requested 3,000 USD to enhance her business. She will use the loan to buy a bigger oven, a refrigrator, and working materials like flour.

Hanin and her husband are working from their house currently and they hope in the future to have their own pastry shop. Hanin appears in the photo making some pastries.

loans.use: To buy a big refrigrator, a big oven and more flour

loans.name: Ochirbat

texts.en:
Ochirbat O. is 25 years old and lives with her parents in a house in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. She operates a clothing trading business, primarily selling undergarments, in the city. She started her business in 2009 and has quickly built a stable operation. She works very hard and is gaining valuable business experience everyday. O. hopes continued growth will allow her to expand her operation in the future.

She is a very passionate person who is very eager to succeed in life. She says, "I hope to have my own shop in the future." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase more undergarments to sell at her clothing store.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase more undergarments to sell at her clothing store

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
Mohira J., 24 years old and living with her parents, is a well-known seamstress in her community, having worked there for more than nine years.  She decided to take advantage of her reputation five years ago and bought a tailoring machine, providing tailoring services since then to the community.  Mohira now has a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are young girls ordering the national dresses. In this way, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. Now she is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni to purchase new modern fabrics for sewing dresses. You can help improve the quality of life of her family. Mohira and her family are grateful for your generosity and support.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes:  its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
	
However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of new modern fabrics for sewing dresses.

loans.name: Anagonou

texts.fr: A. Anagonou est née en 1962 à Bohicon dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Anagonou vit à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis près de 20 ans. Anagonou est mariée à MAKPONDEHOU Roger, un jardiner. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Anagonou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Anagonou n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Anagonou vend des légumes (carottes, choux, etc.), de la pomme de terre et aussi des œufs. C’est depuis environs 30 ans que Anagonou mène cette activité. Anagonou est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l’institution et qui ont été bien remboursés. Anagonou voudrait agrandir son activité pour faire face à la demande de la clientèle en période de fêtes de fin d’année. C’est pourquoi Anagonou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Anagonou A. was born in 1962 in the Atlantique region of Bénin. She has lived in Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, for 20 years. Anagonou is married to Roger Makpondehou, a gardener. The couple takes care of four children, two of whom are their biological children. Some of the children are in school. Anagonou lives with her children and her husband. Together, the couple supports the family. Anagonou did not go to school. To make ends meet, she sells vegetables (carrots, cabbage, etc.), potatoes, and eggs. She has done this work for about 30 years. Anagonou is an old client of ALIDé (Asociacion Latinoamericana de Instituciones Financieras de Desarrollo), having already received and repaid two loans from the institution. She would like to expand her business to meet the increased demand of customers during the end-of-year holiday season. This is why Anagonou is asking for a third loan.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of carrots, cabbage, baskets of potatoes, and cartons of eggs

loans.name: David D.'s Group

texts.en:
These are staff members of an Institution in Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo to seek a loan in order to supplement their monthly salaries. With a loan, they can buy or invest in something that they could otherwise have not been able to do with their salaries alone. But with a loan, some of these staff can pay school fees for their children; others will use it to buy a piece of land for the purpose of constructing a house in the future; some will use it to buy house building materials;  while others will use it to buy pieces of furniture or invest in a business. 
The leader of this team of borrowers is David, on the left, back row. David is a Revenue Collector at the office and has been working in this capacity for nine years. He is forty-eight years of age, married to teacher and they have three children and four foster children. Two of their children are in primary school and five are in senior secondary school. David will use his share of the loan to pay school fees and other school related charges for his children and foster children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children and foster children

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala constitué de huit femmes dont 5 célibataires et 3 qui sont mariées dans des ménages  monogames. Elles ont  en moyenne  26 ans, 1 enfant et habitent dans le Camp Militaire de Ségou  (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage (car sont soient enfants ou épouses de militaires) et font partie d’une  même association traditionnelle d’entraide.
Ce groupe de femmes fait l’achat vente d’articles divers de commerce de différentes sortes. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel  elles sont à leur sont à leur 1er  prêt solidaire. 
Ce  prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 80 paires de chaussures tapettes et baby, une gamme très variée de crèmes, de laits  pour le corps, de pommades pour les cheveux , 40flacons de parfums, des déodorants, 50 paquets de mèches, une ½ balle de pull-overs pour enfants, des condiments alimentaires (1 panier de tomates fraîches, 2 grandes boites de concentrée de tomate, 1sac de choux pommés, 6 paquets de divers cubes maggi : maggi poulet, jumbo, maggi oignon), 2 kg de poivre,  25kg de viande  et de foie et des ingrédients  pour la grillade de brochettes. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en chaussures à Ségou et à Bamako, en produits de beauté  au grand marché de Ségou, en mèches  à Bamako, la friperie et les condiments alimentaires à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, la viande, le foie et les ingrédients pour la grillade au marché château. Les articles sont revendus au marché de Ségou Coura, à domicile et en ambulant dans le quartier et  à l’intérieur du camp militaire. La vente est effectuée  au comptant, en détail  et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel  de 24.500FCFA  qui servira à rembourser le prêt, à satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux à participer aux événements sociaux.
NB : Fatoumata  Diabaté absente de la photo de groupe était empêchée pour raison de funérailles.
texts.en:
The Kotognontala group consists of eight women, including five who are single and three who are married and in monogamous households. On average they are 26 years old with one child, and they live in the Military Camp of Segou (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). They came to know each other through their community ties (as they are all either children or wives of soldiers), and they are part of the same traditional association for mutual assistance.

This group of women buys and sells various types of commercial items. In hopes of increasing the volume of their business, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso from which they are taking first joint loan. This loan will be used to buy 80 pairs of sandals and baby shoes, a wide variety of creams, body lotions, hair pomades, 40 bottles of perfume, deodorant, 50 packets of hair extensions, a half bale of children's sweaters, food condiments (1 basket of fresh tomatoes, 2 large cans of tomato concentrate, 1 bag of cabbage, 6 packets of various Maggi cubes: Maggi chicken, jumbo, Maggi onion), 2 kg of pepper, 25 kg of meat and liver, and ingredients for shish kebabs. They purchase the shoes in Segou and Bamako, the beauty products from the general market of Segou, the hair extensions in Bamako, the second-hand clothes and condiments from the weekly fair in Segou, and the meat, liver and grilling ingredients from the "château" market. The items are resold either in the Segou Coura market, from home, or by traveling in the area and inside the military camp. The sales are made in cash, in retail, and by credit to a customer base of women and men. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 24,500 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan, to satisfy small family needs, and to participate in social events.

NB: Fatoumata Diabaté is absent from the group photo due to a funeral.


Translated from French by Jarred Taylor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various items

loans.name: Gunsennorov

texts.en:
Gunsennorov N. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Zavkhan province in Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His oldest son works as a carpenter and his youngest two are both university students.

N. operates a transportation service in his town. He uses his large van to transport people to his province from the surrounding provinces and back again. N. started his business in 2000 and has gained much experience and a good reputation as a driver over the years. In 2005 he used his savings to trade in his old van for a new one.

His business is very important to him and he works hard so that he can provide for his children's education. He must pay 4,500,000 tugrugs (~3100 USD) tuition each year for both of his youngest sons. It is quite expensive in Mongolia, but he says, "Education is the one thing that helps people get decent jobs and lead happy lives. For that reason, all I want is to support my son's education."

N. is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100) loan to purchase machinery parts for his van and pay a portion of his son's tuition fees.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase parts for his van and pay a portion of his son's tuition fees

loans.name: Agalua

texts.en:
Agalua L. is a 54-year-old woman living in the town of Salelavalu Uta. She is engaged and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Agalua owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting bananas for sale. Agalua has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Agalua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agalua has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Agalua is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Agalua plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr: H. Victoire est née en 1975 au Bénin. Victoire vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis près de 20 ans. Victoire est mariée à KAKPO René, un agent de sécurité. Le couple a cinq enfants en charge, dont quatre sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Victoire n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Victoire vend du pain à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. Victoire  mène également comme activité secondaire, la vente de vin de palme à son domicile. C’est dans les boulangeries à Cotonou, que Victoire s’approvisionne en pain. Victoire a déjà 13 ans d’expérience dans cette activité, et est à son troisième crédit. Victoire a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. C’est en vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’étendre plus son activité, que Victoire sollicite ce troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Victoire H. was born in 1975 in Benin. She has been living for nearly 20 years in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to René Kakpo, a security guard. They care for five children, of whom four are their own. All the children attend school and live with the parents. The couple provides together for the family. Victoire didn't attend school.

To meet her expenses, Victoire sells bread, both from her home and hawking in the streets. She has another activity, namely selling palm wine from her home. Victoire gets her supply of bread from the bakeries in Cotonou. She has already 13 years experience in this activity. This is her third loan. She has repaid on schedule her first two loans with Alidé. Now she came to Alidé and applied for this third loan to increase her working capital and boost her activity.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baskets of bread

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en:
Pepe M. is a 71-year-old woman living in the town of Auala. She is married and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Pepe owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Pepe has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 250 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Pepe joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pepe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Pepe is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Pepe plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Eniola

texts.en:
Eniola is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a printer and he also supports the home.

To make a living, Eniola sells groceries at retail prices from the front of her house in Ibadan, Oyo state. She is happy because of the high season and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
S. Farida is a very hardworking woman and knows that each day she has to give her best effort and all her courage. She is married and has three children.

Farida works raising cattle and feeding them with the goal of later selling them. This activity gives her feelings of satisfaction because it allows her to provide a considerable amount of the household income. She makes sure not to neglect her role as a mother, because she’s also very dedicated to lovingly raising her adorable little daughter.

Farida wants to improve her stable stalls and produce milk in a quantity sufficient for selling it commercially. It is for this reason that she’s requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni to buy small cattle and fodder for her animals. Please support this woman who is determined to change the course of her life with dedication and hard work.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase small cattle and feed

loans.name: Gbonkolenken Group

texts.en:
This is Mariama B., Fatmata C., Isatu F. and Hawanatu K.. They named their group Gbonkolenken. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They are requesting for a loan of SLL 2,600.00.00. With this loan, they will be able to increase the sizes and qualities of their businesses and consequently make better profit and improve their standard of living.

Mariama B. (right) is the leader of this group. Mariama is forty-five years of age. She was born in Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone. She is married to a teacher and they have five children. Three of her children are in secondary school and one is in secondary school. Mariama sells cooked rice, vegetables, and meat, and has been in this business for three years now. Mariama will use her share of the loan to buy bags of rice and gallons of palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), and to renovate her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy rice and palm oil, and to renovate her restuarant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a trader who sells mobile accessories and radios at Kortubuma in the central business market in Bo. He is married and has four dependents: two kids, mother and his wife. He dropped out of junior secondary school and has spent 17 years in business.

James also sells jewelry to add to his income. James intends to buy additional stock and to rent a shop. He hopes to use the proceeds from the loan to complete his house and pay his kids' school fees. His wife at times assists him in his business when he is not around and normally buys his stock from Guinea.

James has been a client with very good credit history.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone accessories and radios

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James M. has owned and run an electronics repair shop called Line Electronics Repair for two years. He was previously employed in a similar repair shop and ultimate went out on his own. He fixes radios, TVs, DVD players, amplifiers and antennae. Line Electronics is a secure stall located in a mixed use area in Spaki / Majengo, a neighborhood in Mombasa. His business is a mix of 2/3rds new customers and 1/3 repeat business. He struggles when clients do not have the cash to pick up their repaired items and when he has to get spare parts from Nairobi.

James is using this KES 20,000 loan to expand his offering and sell car stereos, both new and used, and new cable / antenna wire. James' goal for his business is to expand the shop and offer more spare parts and wider repair services. He is not married yet and his goal is to have his own house. His customers say he is smart in his work (he gets referrals when other technicians have failed) and hard-working.

loans.use: To expand product offering to include car stereos, antenna and cable wire

loans.name: Johnson Hagin

texts.en:
Johnson Hagin is husband to Anne, and they have five children aged 21, 19, 17, 16, and 14. He does mobile retail selling of goods on his wheelbarrow in Kakamega town and has been in this business for the last eight years. He stocks soap, matchboxes, pens and other small household items. He also does some farming in his home area, which is on the outskirts of the town.

This is Johnson's second loan from KADET and he intends to utilize these funds in purchasing more stock of items that he has traditionally sold, and use part of it to diversifying into cereal sales. He feels this will increase his sales and profits ultimately.

Johnson aspires to open a wholesale shop in future and also to own a residential building in the town.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his mobile retail goods sales

loans.name: Sènan

texts.fr: M. Sènan est née en 1981 à Adja au Mono au Bénin. Il y a 28 ans de cela que Sènan vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BENSAN Sévérin, un revendeur de pièces détachées, Sènan à trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont ses propres enfants. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Sènan vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son conjoint. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Sènan n’a fait que l’école primaire. Depuis 7 ans environs, Sènan vend des divers (savons, omo, lait, papiers torchons, etc.) et aussi du maïs à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Sènan s’approvisionne. Sènan a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Sènan ambitionne devenir plus tard une grande commerçante. Sènan souhaite augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d’agrandir son activité. C’est pour cela que Sènan sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sènan M. was born in 1981 in Adja, department of Mono, in Benin. She has lived for the past 28 years in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Séverin Bensan, a retailer of spare parts. Sènan provides for three children, of whom two are her own. Some children attend school. She lives with her children and her husband. She and her husband provide together for their family. Sènan attended only primary school.

For about seven years Sènan has been selling various articles (soap, washing powder, milk, paper towels, etc.) and also corn from her home. It is in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, that Sènan gets her supplies. She received already two loans from Alidé, which she repaid on schedule. Her ambition is to become a great merchant. She wants to increase her working capital and bolster her activity. This is why Sènan came to Alidé and applied for her third loan.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soap, washing powder, milk and a sack of corn

loans.name: No Joke Group

texts.en:
This is Fatmata B., Christiania E., Francis K., Alima S. and Mbalu S.. They called their group 'No Joke'. This is the first loan they are receiving from SMT/Kiva, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo. They’re requesting a loan of around SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will help them a lot. They will able to make a lot of profit from the loan, thus able to solve many of their problems.

Fatmata B. (left) is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Tongo, a town in eastern Sierra Leone. She is forty years of age, married to a businessman, and they have two children. One of her children is in university and the other is in senior secondary school II. Fatmata sells shoes, clothes and soft drinks. She has been in business for ten years now. Fatmata will use her share of the loan to buy clothes, shoes, soft drinks and plastic containers of water.

loans.use: Buy clothes, shoes, soft drinks and plastic containers of water

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol T., 29, lives with her husband and their only child in Parola, Tondo, Manila – a shanty town at the edge of Manila Bay.  

Carol has been in business since she was a child.  Now, her sari-sari (general) store is very successful.  She hires an assistant to look after her business.  She earns more than P22,000 in monthly profits.  She saves much of her earnings in preparation for her child’s education.  She is also providing maintenance medications for her sick father.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the summer of 2007.  She has been enjoying the camaraderie of her fellowship group since then.  She is now on her sixth loan cycle.  She has just finished repaying her loan of P15,000 and she has applied for a new loan of P17,000.  She will use the loan proceeds to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

Carol aspires to see her store grow big so she can help employ more people in her community.

 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

loans.name: Gbassay

texts.en:
Gbassay is a petty trader married also to a petty trader with three dependents, one of whom is their son. She trades in cutlery, plastic rubbers, and enamel dishes. After dropping out during senior secondary school some fourteen years ago, she has been in business. She usually travels to a neighbouring country (Guinea) to purchase her stock.

Gbassay intends to use the profit from the loan she is seeking to buy more stock, rent a bigger store to stock her goods and to help her husband to purchase land.

loans.use: To buy cutlery and  plastics rubbers

loans.name: Teresia Njeri

texts.en:
Teresia Njeri is a widowed lady aged 51 and a mother of five, aged 33, 30, 29, 24, and 18. She has been selling motor spare parts and power saws for the last 18 years. She managed to feed her children and educate them from the income she gets from this business.

Teresia learnt about KADET through a friend who was an existing client of KADET. This will be her first loan from KADET Ltd.

With this loan, she intends to incorporate a wider range of spare parts to compensate for the income previously derived from sales of power saws. This is because sales for power saws have gone down substantially due to government regulations against deforestation and increased awareness of environmental conservation.

She aspires to expand the business and also diversify into subsistence farming.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts for sale

loans.name: Oka

texts.en:
Oka T. is a 34-year-old woman living in the town of Tufutafoe. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Oka owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Oka has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Oka joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oka has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Oka is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Oka plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jacob Omeno

texts.en:
Jacob Omeno is 37 years old and married to Everlyne, who is 31 and a salon operator by profession. They have a daughter, 9, and two sons, age 6 and 3 respectively. Jacob makes sandals, brake pads and bicycle rubber fittings from used tires. The sandals are popular in the neighborhood due to their durability. He has been in this business for the last 19 years. 

This is Jacob's second loan from KADET, a Kiva partner, and he intends to use it to purchase more stock of used tires.

Jacob aspires to purchase land and develop a commercial building where he can operate his shoe-making business.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more used tires for his art-and-craft business and diversify to farming

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en:
This is Zosima M., a beauty salon owner of seven years.  She lives with her husband Miguel and their three children in Parola, Tondo, Manila.  

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2004 and has since been enjoying economic improvements.  The low-interest and easy-to-pay loans provided by the cooperative helped her improve her beauty parlor.  She now has a second floor extension which serves as the family’s living area.  From her profits which she has been saving through the years, she was able to open a sari-sari (general) store.  From her two businesses, she now earns more than P70,000 a month.  She has one employee.

Zosima needs a new loan in the amount of P24,000 to serve as additional capital for her beauty salon.  She will stock up on salon supplies.  She dreams of establishing salon branches in other areas. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Purchase of salon supplies

loans.name: Together As One Ii Group

texts.en:
Here are Abass M. B., Abdulai F., Abdul K., and Idrissa K.. These entrepreneurs named their group Together As One. This will be their first loan from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in terms of size and quality. This will enable them to make more sales, increase profits, and consequently improve their standard of living.

Abass M. B. (second from left) is the leader of this group. Abass is twenty-three years of age. He is single with one young child. Abass dropped out of school three years ago since he could not afford to pay the school fees. He then started trading. He now sells tapes, radios and mobile phone accessories. He has been in this business for two years. With his share of the loan, he will buy more tapes, radios and mobile phone accessories to sell.

loans.use: Buy tapes, radios and mobile phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Adeline

texts.fr: D. Adeline est née en 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Adeline vit au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, depuis sa naissance. Mariée à AGOSSOU Paul, un enseignant, Adeline est mère de trois enfants. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge. Certains de leurs enfants sont scolarisés. Tous les enfants vivent ensemble à Cadjèhoun avec leurs parents. Adeline vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Adeline n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Adeline vend des tissus par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Adeline s’approvisionne. Adeline mène cette activité depuis 8 ans. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Adeline compte agrandir son activité, pour mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse de la clientèle en période de fêtes de fin d’année. C’est pourquoi Adeline sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Adeline D. was born in 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Adeline has lived in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou since she was born. She is married to Paul AGOSSOU, a teacher. Adeline is the mother of three children. The couple supports another child. Some of their children attend school. All the children live in Cadjèhoun with their parents. Adeline helps her husband with the family expenses.

Adeline has never attended school. To take care of her needs, Adeline sells cloth through the distribution system. She buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Adeline has been in this business for 8 years.

She is a previous client of ALIDé who has already received two loans that were repaid fully. Adeline wishes to enlarge her activity to better meet the demand of her numerous customers during the year-end festivities. This is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pieces of cloth

loans.name: Taualofa

texts.en:
Taualofa F. is a 59-year-old woman living in the town of Fagasa. She is married and has 13 adult children. To make a living, Taualofa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Taualofa has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 280 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Taualofa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Taualofa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Taualofa is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Taualofa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Dinah Jepchirchir

texts.en:
Dinah T. is 44 years old and married to William Cheburet, who is 48 years old. They have been blessed with five children, namely Mark, who is in college; Sophie and Moses, who are in high school; and Jepkurui and Jemutai, who are in the primary level of schooling.

Dinah runs a grocery and owns a kiosk, which she started four years ago. She gets a profit of 800 Kenyan shillings per month from the business and her additional income comes from her husband and college-going son, who does menial labor. 

Dinah has borrowed Kshs 10,000 from KADET LTD., a Kiva partner, and this will be her first loan from an MFI. She wants to buy half a sack of maize flour for kshs 1,200, 10kg of sugar for Kshs 900, bar soap for Kshs 800, tea leaves and sweets for Kshs 600 and paraffin for Kshs 500 for her kiosk. For her grocery business, she wants to buy sukumawiki (kale), cabbages, onions and tomatoes for Kshs 4,000. The remaining Kshs 2,000 she will save for restocking her business in a future period.

Dinah’s business is situated along Nakuru-Kabarnet highway and her customers are mainly residents of Chemogoch, who are low-income earners and travelers who pass by the Nakuru-Kabarnet highway. If this loan boosts her business, she plans to smoothly repay the loan and diversify her stock by purchasing goods that she has not stocked before. Dinah dreams of being able to educate her children to the highest level possible and she hopes to acquire a pick-up truck in the next four years. This will enable her to expand her retail business by accessing interior areas.

Dinah describes herself as a born-again Christian and a loving and dedicated mother who likes to offer guidance and counseling to children and teenagers. She believes she is a good planner, kind, cheerful and always ready to help others.  


About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To stock a kiosk and grocery

loans.name: Abdulahat

texts.en:
Abdulahat B. is 54 years old and has a very collaborative and supportive wife who joins him in tending to their crops. This couple has two children. Abdulahat and his wife have been working in agriculture for many years as it's their livelihood. He likes the earth to be well worked. He plants cabbage, potato and onion. His wife and children work for the family's daily income. The youngest is 22 years old and helps take care of the crops, but then has to go and study. 

Now Abdulahat needs a loan of $1,300. He is planning to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer for sowing his crops. His goal, with time, is to plant larger quantities and to educate his children. With your help, this will be possible.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for growing seasonal vegetables

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is single and sells children and men’s wear in a shop which he rents and is located in the central market area. After graduating from high school, Emmanuel has been doing business for about six years now.

In order to respond to the needs of his customers, Emmanuel is seeking a loan to buy more stock for his shop. Quite apart from buying more stock, he intends to use proceeds from the loan to buy a plot of land which he has already identified and to save some money to marry his longtime girl friend. He spends his entire time in the business.

loans.use: To buy  clothing

loans.name: Fikry

texts.en:
Fikry is a young Palestinian man living in Biet Leed village next to Tulkarem. He is married with three children. He has special needs so he uses a wheelchair to move around. 

Fikry owns an Internet Café and he also fixes computers. He has requested 3,000 USD to bring more computers to his café. He appears in the photo at his store where he fixes computers.

loans.use: To bring more computers to his café

location.town: Biet Leed, Tulkarem City, West Bank

loans.name: Mohamed Patrick

texts.en:
Mohamed is the proprietor of a Relaxation Bar called M&V and sells liquor and soft drinks. His bar is located by a popular motor park called Shellmingo in BO Town. He is married with two kids, both in nursery school. Before getting into business, Mohamed was a maintenance and supply officer of a gas station, a position he held until his resignation to start up his own business some two years ago.

Mohamed seeks a loan to buy more liquor for his store, buy a piece of land to build his own bar, and take care of his family.

loans.use: buy additional drinks

loans.name: Lagilelei

texts.en:
Lagilelei A. is a 22-year-old woman living in the town of Puleia. She is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Lagilelei owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Lagilelei has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 450 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lagilelei joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lagilelei is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Lagilelei plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Pamela Aoko

texts.en:
Pamela Aoko is a 36-year-old married lady with three children aged 14, 12 and 7. Her husband Agripa who is 40 years old is a teacher by profession. Pamela operates a boutique and salon, a business she has been in for the last nine years in the heart of Kisumu City.

She is among the first clients who joined KADET since its inception in Kisumu. She learnt about KADET through World Vision, the mother organization where she was a volunteer. She later on left KADET after her first loan to go to college and returned when she completed her college education.

Pamela started her business by selling ladies' clothes in an open air market, before she moved to the stall. She currently has two employees who assist her in the salon business.

This is her third loan from KADET and she hopes to use this money to purchase beauty chemicals, new shoes, bags and children's wear in readiness for the festive season when she expects her sales will go up.

She aspires to open a wholesale boutique shop.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more stock of beauty chemicals, shoes, bags

loans.name: Metuli

texts.en: Metuli S. is a 52-year-old woman living in the town of Fagasa. She is married and has five school-aged children. Metuli owns and operates a business planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 200 WST a month. In 2008, Metuli joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Metuli is now requesting a new loan of 1,000 WST which will again be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. The loan will be her 2nd from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is 33 years old and married with a child. Her husband also supports the home. She sells groceries and medicines at retail prices to make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state. 

She is happy because of the high season and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and medicines to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and groceries to sell

loans.name: Laumata

texts.en: Laumata L. is a 28-year-old woman living in the town of Asaga. She is single and has one infant child. Laumata owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 500 WST a month. In 2009, Laumata joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 1,000 WST which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. The loan will be her first from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
